TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the announcement last Friday of a record current account deficit for September and to the extremely volatile movements in world stock exchanges in the last 24 hours, which are undoubtedly of concern to both sides of the House. I ask the Treasurer, against the background of those developments, whether he still regards the domestic policy settings for the Australian economy as being adequate to protect our economy to the extent possible against external shocks and, in particular, I ask him whether the Government will still be supporting a 1.5 per cent first tier wage increase for all Australian employees at the national wage case commencing in Melbourne tomorrow.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is yes and yes. We do regard the pace of adjustment in Australia as being adequate to deal with our current account imbalance. Let me repeat what I said abroad when talking not only to finance Ministers and officials of governments but also to major financial institutions: it is entirely accurate to say that the pace of economic adjustment in Australia far outstrips that of any other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country. As a result of that there is an enhanced level of confidence in our capacity to adjust to our diminished terms of trade. Again, one must remember and put in context the extent of our terms of trade decline.

ANSWER.PARA: When I was speaking in Germany I gave the figures since 1984. The German economy has experienced a 30 per cent improvement in its terms of trade since 1984; in the same period we have experienced a 16 per cent decline. That is a very large shift, a very large change and it is that to which we are adjusting and that is why we are not rebuilding the secondary industry base which the coalition managed to decimate in the years of its last Government. Because we were always sold the line that only commodities mattered and we left all of our eggs in the commodities basket, now that commodities in the broader sense in terms of price buoyancy have failed us, as usual it is left to the Australian Labor Party to clean up. We are making that adjustment.

The Leader also asked me about the current account deficit for the month of September. Of course, those figures are evidence again of a fair amount of month to month volatility in the collection of data, but if we look at the figures over nine months we see that for the three months to September, for a start, there is a $615m improvement over the same period last year, and the current account has improved by $1.5 billion, to $9.8 billion, for the first nine months of this calendar year. I can only add that the quarterly pattern of the current account is entirely consistent with the Budget time forecast for the current quarter.

Let me say, in terms of the adjustments that Australia is making, that as a result of this Government's changes Australia is better placed to face whatever international conditions may come its way, and I think those changes are being looked upon as changes of quality and magnitude by all of the major financial institutions. I simply make the point that one has to smile at members of the Opposition who are proposing by implication that they would be adjusting faster when the policy underpinning the adjustment they would be having says that what we need to fix the state of our indebtedness is an unfunded tax cut which would lift Australian living standards and pay ourselves more while the rest of the world is paying itself less. I make the point that around the places that matter-in New York, London and Frankfurt, let alone within the bureaucracies-those people opposite are treated as an absolute standing joke. The last election campaign shot to pieces any credibility they might have had remaining about economic competence and as a result they have a lot of rebuilding to do. When they come to understand how their Leader's reputation has been shot to bits in those markets, they will start to understand that his political reputation will be shot to bits with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade been drawn to reports of recent demonstrations in Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, by supporters of Tibetan independence which have involved clashes with the authorities, violence and allegations of severe human rights abuses? Can the Minister advise the House of the Government's response to these occurrences?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since 27 September there have been several demonstrations by Tibetans in Lhasa, the capital of the Tibetan autonomous region, and those demonstrations were calling for independence from China. Reports of the situation are not entirely consistent but demonstrations were accompanied by violence and at least six deaths occurred as a result. The Australian Government has noted Press reports that the police in Tibet used extremely harsh measures against Buddhist monks during the demonstrations, that over 500 arrests had been made and that there had been a crackdown on Tibetans demanding greater independence for Tibet.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been allegations in the Press of torture, beatings and harsh prison conditions for those in detention. From 1959, and particularly during the Chinese cultural revolution, the Tibetan people, their religion and culture suffered greatly as a result of oppressive central government policies. The present Chinese leadership has acknowledged the failure of previous policies and in the past few years has been promoting economic development, greater tolerance of religion and respect for Tibet's culture and religion.

Australia condemns abuses of human rights wherever and whenever they occur. While Australia acknowledges that Tibet is part of China, the Government and people of Australia remain deeply concerned that ethnic Tibetans should be treated according to internationally accepted standards of human rights. The concern of the Australian Government in all of these respects has been registered with the Chinese Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the Minister give the House any indication of public reaction to his announcement last week of a proposed advisory structure for his portfolio?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I announced a proposal by the Government to reform the advisory structures to the portfolio to better co-ordinate advice coming to the Government across the range of education and training activities. The reason that we continue to need advisory structures is that there is more than just the Commonwealth involved in the education and training system. First of all, the State governments play such an important role, both in schools education and in the technical and further education system. As well, employers and unions have a vital interest in improving the array of training opportunities that are available to build up the skills base within Australia, which is so important to underpinning the revitalisation of our manufacturing industries in particular. Of course, there are those who work within the education system who should be appropriately represented in relation to any policy formulation and advice coming to us. There is also the peculiar situation of universities and colleges which sit as independent bodies responsible in a statutory sense to State parliaments, but which, nevertheless, are funded by us. Within that complex array of arrangements, we decided to change the existing arrangements for advice coming to us on education and training. I think that there has been relatively widespread support for these changes from the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the unions which it represents--
—Why not? It is part of the club.

—The most enthusiastic support has come from the Confederation of Australian Industry and they have also attracted support from the Business Council of Australia (BCA). Is the BCA part of the club too? Are these organisations part of Jimmy's club over there? Unions at this stage have been broadly receptive to these arrangements, including those unions which represent teachers and academics. There has been some concern, particularly from parent groups, but I think that concern is misplaced because they will continue to be involved and to have an opportunity to approach me and the Department in relation to the important programs that we provide for the schools.

ANSWER.PARA: Some people have said that we have not gone far enough. The New South Wales Minister for Education and the Sydney Morning Herald seem to be doing a little double act on this. They say we should not have had any advisory structures at all; that all the advice should have come directly to me and all the decisions should have been made directly by me. I think that is perhaps too sweeping, bearing in mind not only Australian Labor Party policy but also the question of needing to co-ordinate advice in view of the very many players that take part in this area. I say to the honourable member for Herbert that there are some very interesting proposals coming to us in relation to extending higher and tertiary education opportunities within north Queensland. North Queensland has been an area of traditionally low participation rates and, despite the superb work of the James Cook University in recent times, we are looking at ways in which we can extend opportunities for students within that region and north of Townsville.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to the findings of the Monash University's Centre for Policy Studies that single income families with two children earning $23,000 a year are $266 a year worse off than one year ago and that double income families with two children earning $55,650 are $755 worse off due to the Government's changes in taxes and benefits and the 7 per cent fall in real average earnings under Labor. Will the Minister tell the House where the conspicuous wealth is that he expressed so much concern about, and why is he not concentrating on the welfare of lower and middle class Australians who are being taxed into poverty under Labor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for raising the question of equity and fairness in relation to the distribution of income, particularly in respect of Australian families. Frankly, I would have thought that fairness and equity were not in the lexicon of the contemporary Liberal Party. The Liberal Party's record when in government in terms of the impact on family living standards is a particularly sorry one. The most important evidence of that assertion was its inability to do that which is fundamental to maintaining living standards, and that is to achieve an effective management of the economy which does not allow the massive blowout of unemployment that occurred during the Liberals' period in government. There were 185,000 jobs lost in the last two years of that period. When considering equity and fairness for Australian families, it is hard to believe that anything is more important than a commitment to employment growth. The record of this Government as against the record of that earlier government in terms of job creation and the reduction of unemployment stands out.

ANSWER.PARA: To come more specifically to the issues raised in the honourable member's question, which go to the report in this morning's newspapers regarding the Centre for Policy Studies and the Institute of Family Studies, I point out that both groups commented on the relevant family policies issued during the most recent election. I recall that the Institute of Family Studies in response to the program we announced, particularly that relating to the family allowance supplement, made it clear that, whatever else might be said about that policy, it was highly equitable. I recall that at the end of the report our package was described as a guaranteed minimum income for children. When one looks at welfare and the position of low income families, one sees the quite massive gains that will come to families arising from that package. For example, a beneficiary family with three children at March 1983 was some $21 below the poverty line; as a result of the package, by December this year that family will be some $4 above the poverty line-and could be as much as $20 above the poverty line, depending on the ages of the children. In times of severe economic difficulty, times in which all governments are having difficulty managing their economies, this Government has very successfully managed the economy. We are able to deliver very significant gains to very low income families.

In terms of the real income levels of more middle income families on which the honourable member has commented and on which the report this morning commented, one must look at more than income transfers. One must certainly look at the tax changes which this Government has made, but also one must look at a whole range of measures which go not only to employment, which is quite fundamental, but also to schemes to get young middle income families into their first homes, into massive expansion of child care and the development of education and training opportunities which have substantially increased retention rates. In other words, one must look at the whole picture. When this Opposition went into the election campaign on the theme of family living standards, with speech after speech from Opposition members about declining living standards for middle Australia, the people of Australia said, `What we are most concerned about is to continue to get responsible and fair government'. We were re-elected on the basis of our commitment to maintaining employment and growth and the living standards of all families, but especially very low income families.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PERSIAN GULF: ATTACK ON UNITED STATES FLAGGED TANKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade advise the House of the Government's reaction to recent events in the Persian Gulf, including the attack on the United States flagged tanker and the possible response from the United States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been briefed by the United States concerning the latest incidents in the Persian Gulf between the United States and Iran. In essence, the United States flagged tanker Sea Isle City was attacked in Kuwait territorial waters on 16 October by a missile believed to have been fired by Iranian forces. On 19 October United States naval vessels, having provided prior warning, struck an Iranian platform in international waters in the Persian Gulf. According to the United States Secretary of Defense, the Iranian platform had been used to mount radar surveillance, report on convoy movement, launch small boat attacks against non-belligerent shipping and, last week, to fire at United States military helicopters.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Evans said on 22 September in relation to the Iran Ajr incident, Australia maintains an absolute commitment to the right of freedom of navigation, including the right of all countries of the Persian Gulf to export their oil. All attacks on merchant shipping are condemned and deplored by the Australian Government as a violation of international law.

The United States response to the attack on the Sea Isle City, according to the information presently available, was conducted within its inherent right of self-defence under Article 51 of the United Nations Charter and represented a proportionate response to an ongoing threat to American vessels and crews. The Security Council has been notified of the United States action. These latest incidents add to the importance of further efforts by the United Nations Secretary-General to seek a ceasefire and negotiated settlement to the Iran-Iraq war on the basis of United Nations Security Council Resolution 598. Australia will continue to work to encourage the achievement of that objective.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Has he seen reports of plague locust activity in western New South Wales? Further, is the Minister aware of fears expressed by some landowners that spraying against these locusts could result in excess chemical levels in livestock for slaughter? Given the devastating effects of migrating locust swarms, will the Minister advise whether there is any basis for these fears?

—Yes, I have seen the reports. I thank the honourable member for raising this matter, which is of vital importance to people in the rural community. The Australian Plague Locust Commission is monitoring plague locust activity across western New South Wales, in Queensland and South Australia. The standard practice for the control of locusts in New South Wales involves the spraying of insecticides by both landholders and by the Commission. Recently there has been concern about chemical residues in beef, which has led to a reluctance on the part of some New South Wales landholders to spray immature locusts. That concern is utterly unfounded. The insecticide fenitrothion, which is used by the Plague Locust Commission and is supplied to landholders in New South Wales by the Pastures Protection Board, is based on a different group of compounds to that involved in the beef testing incident. The chemicals detected in excess levels in beef were organochlorine compounds. Fenitrothion is not as soluble in animal fats as organochlorine compounds. It is only moderately toxic and it readily breaks down in animals and in the environment. I am assured that if the standard withholding periods for livestock are observed, no excess residue levels in animals should result. I emphasise to the House, and to the farmers concerned, that the successful control of plague locusts depends on the active co-operation of the landholders themselves. I hope that the information which I have provided to the honourable member, given his concern and the importance of the matter, will encourage farmers in locust affected areas, who have previously been reluctant to spray, to take action as quickly as possible.

—Can the Minister for Community Services and Health inform the House as to details of the Federal Government's financial offer to the Queensland Government to assist with the transfer of nurse education from hospital based courses to colleges of advanced education? Can the Minister inform the House of the progress being made in commencing the transfer in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Yesterday's decision by the Queensland Cabinet not to proceed with the transfer of nurse education from hospitals to colleges of advanced education (CAEs), with the assistance of Commonwealth funding, is an insult to the nursing profession in Queensland and will prove a real blow to the health system of that State. Every other State is now either proceeding with that transfer or has completed its plans for transferring nurses from hospital based education to the CAEs. It is important to point out that the States have always borne the responsibility for and the cost of nurse education. What the Commonwealth has offered are supplementary moneys to assist in the transfer being made. Every other State in the Commonwealth has accepted that position, that they continue to bear the major cost of nurse education, which has always been a State responsibility, but the Commonwealth will provide supplementary moneys to assist in that transfer. In fact it is the first time that the Commonwealth has made a contribution to nurse education.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, the Queensland Government is saying, `We won't transfer unless the Commonwealth pays the whole bill for nurse education'. That is quite contrary to the responsibilities the State has borne since Federation and quite contrary to the attitude taken by every other State in the Commonwealth. It may well be true that in Queensland the savings will not be as much as in some of the other States because the evidence is that Queensland has spent much less on nurse education in its hospitals than have the other States. One has only to compare curriculum hours in the hospitals in Queensland with those in the other States. But I do want to point out the consequences to Queensland of refusing the Commonwealth offer which, as I have said, has now been accepted by every other State. Every other State is in the process of transferring its nurses from hospital based education to the CAEs, or at least has completed its detailed planning to do so.

First of all, already the Queensland Government has lost something like $1.5m in assistance money which has now gone to the other States who wish to accelerate the transfer. That money is lost and Queensland will continue to lose money if it fails to take up the offer made by the Commonwealth. But, even more important for nurses in Queensland, in the future it will be increasingly difficult for them to work in other States where the educational standards are now quite different. So, in the long run, it will penalise severely nurses in Queensland. Perhaps most important of all in an age when everyone, governments and industry, is demanding higher levels of education to fit people for the challenges of the twenty-first century, and when every nurse organisation in this country and every State government has accepted the need for that advancement in basic nurse education, Queensland's refusal to move will damage not only the nursing profession but also the whole health system in Queensland.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DETENTION OF AUSTRALIAN CITIZEN IN SOUTH AFRICA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It concerns the detention of Mr Ian Fry in South Africa. Is the Minister aware that Mr Fry, editor of the Broadmeadows Observer and an Australian delegate to the World Conference on Religion and Peace being held in South Africa, was taken from the home of the President of the World Conference by South African police at 11.30 p.m. on Thursday, 24 September, questioned during the night and threatened with deportation? Is the Minister also aware that Mr Fry was on a five-nation tour of Africa sponsored by the Uniting Church in Australia? Does the Minister approve of the actions of the South African Government? What steps are being taken to follow through on this matter?

—The behaviour of the authorities representing the South African Government is condemned. Australia has made representations, and continues to do so, in regard to the treatment Mr Fry was subjected to. He arrived in South Africa on 23 September. He was detained and interrogated by South African security police from 2315 hours on 24 September until 0630 hours the following day. He was released and permitted to continue his visit to South Africa. No explanation was given for his detention under South African emergency regulations, although it was clear that the police were interested in Mr Fry's church contacts in South and southern Africa. As far as we can establish, he was not mistreated while in detention. The Australian Government made, through its Embassy in Pretoria, a strong protest to the South African Foreign Ministry on 25 September over the treatment of Mr Fry who sought an explanation of the reasons for his detention. We followed this up subsequently. We are still awaiting, however, a response from the South African authorities. The Government, of course, deplores the arbitrary detention and interrogation of an Australian citizen in South Africa and will continue to press the South African authorities for a full explanation.

—Can the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories inform the House of progress towards the staging of Expo 88 in Brisbane? Will Expo provide a further boost to Australia's spectacular tourism industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Petrie for his question. It is a timely one in view of the fact that the Expo Committee has staged in King's Hall today-and I think also for tomorrow-a rather spectacular exhibition and model of the expo site in Brisbane. I am very happy to congratulate Sir Llew Edwards, the man in charge of Expo, for his very Australian view of Expo in Brisbane. There have been attempts by certain elements in Queensland to paint Expo as simply a Queensland manifestation of the bicentennial celebrations. That is not the case. Sir Llew Edwards, to his great credit, has been at pains all around the world to indicate that Expo in Brisbane is in fact an Australian exposition, the first we have had since 1888. I would venture to say that this event will be as successful as any Expo staged in the world, certainly since the War. I hope that honourable members will take the opportunity to have a look at the model in King's Hall and also to take home to their electorates and any congregations to whom they happen to speak the message that a visit to Brisbane for Expo 88 would be a very profitable one. Expo 88 will certainly be one of the highlights of the bicentennial year. Of course, the Australian pavilion will also be something of which all members of this Parliament can be proud. I venture to say that, as 32 countries have now accepted invitations to come to Expo-and very likely the total will be 40-this will be the most successful Expo in terms of international participation. I am also very pleased to note that New South Wales, my own State, has agreed to exhibit at Expo in Brisbane.
—At long last.
—I agree with the honourable member. Hopefully Victoria and Western Australia will follow-and maybe Tasmania and the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the second part of the question, which asked whether Expo will contribute to our spectacular growth in tourism, I hope that honourable members have noticed the figures in the papers over the last couple of days indicating a growth of the numbers of Japanese tourists coming to Australia. The figures for August this year indicate that we have doubled the number of Japanese tourists coming to this country compared with August 1986. It is very likely that we will get very close to two million tourists this year. Considering that it took us 195 years up till 1983 to get to 900,000, the growth to two million in four years has been pretty spectacular. This says something first of all about Australia as a destination and, more importantly, about the Government's pursuit of positive tourism policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a message from the Senate concurring in the resolution of the House of Representatives relating to the appointment of a Joint Committee on Electoral Matters, subject to modifications.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senate's message-
The Senate, having considered Message No. of the House of Representatives, has agreed to the following resolution in connection therewith:

(1) That the Senate concurs in the resolution transmitted to the Senate by Message No. 7 of the House of Representatives relating to the appointment of a Joint Committee on Electoral Matters, subject to the following modifications:

``(2) That the committee consist of 10 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 2 Senators to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.'';

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Donald Cameron,Mr Dobie,Mr Hunt,Mr Ruddock,Mr Shipton and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
In the light of our heritage as a nation we humbly ask you to consider our petition to:
Cease current legislative procedure involving the proposed ``Australia Card'', because we believe;
1. That this card will be an immediate infringement upon our civil rights and personal liberties.
2. That no guarantee can be given now or in the future as to the security and privacy of information gained and retained by the Data Bank.

3. That this system of preventing Social Welfare and Tax fraud cannot be conclusively proven and that the ones most likely to be harmed and abused are the innocent, the powerless and the underprivileged of our society. We would remind you that our common Law system is to protect all as innocent until proven guilty.

4. The the recent Federal Election was not our `yes' vote for the ``Australia Card''; in fact less Australians voted for the Labor Government. We therefore call upon you to call a national referendum to deal with this issue.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal to introduce the I.D. (Australia Card). Australian citizens do not need a card as proof of identity and we believe the card to be a gross invasion of our basic rights as free citizens.
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to introduce the I.D. Card without the approval of the Australian people by referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: DOBIE; FISCHER; FISHER; MCARTHUR; MACKELLAR; TUCKEY; WHITE
PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card;

That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;

That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life;
That we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dobie,Mr Tim Fischer,Mr Peter Fisher,Mr McArthur,Mr MacKellar,Mr Tuckey and Mr White.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern:
About the evil caused by the fact that X-rated videos with their depiction of unnatural sex and often horrible violence, are allowed to circulate around Australia from Canberra.
And your petitioners, therefore humbly pray that such circulation be prevented.
The laws regarding obscenity in the media should also be revived and enforced.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Braithwaite,Mr John Brown,Mr Cohen and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for the possession of child pornography, and has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
Make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
Close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X-rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X-rated videos . . .
Because the trade is still flourishing, and its availability escalates sexual crime . . .
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying . . .
Because child pornography pedlars are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence . . .
Because anyone can have these tapes in their possession for private use . . .
Because the Government does not intervene in that.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Mr Campbell,Dr Charlesworth,Mr Rocher and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Cohen,Mr Gorman,Mr Hunt and Mr West.

PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation yet introduced, and that on all the evidence available, it will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID Card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
An ID Card numbering system for all Australians would give future governments tremendous power to collect sensitive information and use it against us.

Criminal elements could benefit by forging cards and documents needed to obtain them, or by illegally accessing the data in the system. The dangers are much greater than with current systems such as Medicare, as the Australia Card number could link so many different confidential records.
The cost to government and private enterprise of implementing the ID Card would be enormous, outweighing any gains. Tax cheats can be stopped more effectively by better checks in the present system.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will reject the Australia Card Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr O'Keefe,Mr Peacock and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Humble Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Government by persisting with the Australia Card Bill has wilfully rejected the advice and recommendations of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia's ``Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card'' which unequivocally rejected the Government's proposal in those words:

``The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2000 public servants within the HIC [Health Insurance Commission], with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which they very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors, and updates information on every person in Australia'' (Report, 4.55, page 148)

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government now withdraw the Bill as being contrary to the Common Law and traditional freedoms we have hitherto enjoyed in Australia, and should the Bill be nevertheless re-introduced, that the Members of the House without regard for party should unamimously reject the Australia Card Bill as being contrary to our personal liberties and the national interest.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Prosser,Mr Rocher and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the proposal:
Is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud, and to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud,
Will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private matter,
Will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer, and
Cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this Legislation. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

We believe the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Business Offices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we oppose plans by Telecom Australia to close many of the Telecom Business Offices (TBOs) and replace them with a reduced service to be co-located with the District Customer Services Office. We believe the public should be able to make telephone bill payments, applications for new services, selection of telephones and complaints, in person at a convenient and easily accessible location. Telecom Business Offices provide this service, and therefore it is wrong that their contribution and performance will only be assessed on their sales revenue.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: instruct the management of Telecom Australia to immediately cease all action to close any Telecom Business Offices, and to re-establish the services provided by TBOs already closed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
We advise that we stand against the Australia Card because of the following points:
The Australia Card is an unacceptable infringement on the freedom and privacy that Australians have been able to take for granted for so long in our democratic society.
The people of Australia should be properly informed of the facts before anything with such far reaching implications as this be brought in,
We call for a referendum on the Australia Card before it is too late,
There is no guarantee that the private information on the computers will remain confidential,
The card will fail to control social security fraud and tax evasion,
The Government will have almost complete control over our lives, through the control of our money,
There is no allowance made for the loss, theft or destruction of the card,
The counterfeiting of cards has been completely ignored,

The people have no real choice whether they take the card or not, as it is needed for most everyday activities, eg. jobs, banking, being admitted to hospital etc. and if not used can result in a $20,000 fine. Where's the democracy in that?
We call on the Government to cease all efforts to enforce the Australia Card on our country immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should not be considered any further, and in the event of it coming again before parliament it should be rejected because:
We do not accept the concept of an ID card as necessary to control social security fraud or tax evasion,

It would be an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy and our democratic society, in particular because it being required to work, operate a bank account, enter hospital or enter into any transaction,
It would cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on tax payers,
It cannot be guaranteed that the aggregated private information would not be misused for other purposes,

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The irresponsibility of the Hawke/Keating Government in adopting a high risk economic strategy.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, you have read the terms of the matter of public importance and, as those listening to the broadcast will know, this is a difficult day for Australia and for many Australians in view of what has transpired on our stock markets. This is not, of course, confined to Australia. It would be easy for an opposition to come into the House to blame the Government and to dump it on the Government, implying, or indeed stating explicitly, that this is all the fault of the Government. But the Opposition is not doing that. What we want to do, among other things, is to ensure that this Government starts to focus on the fundamentals relating to the Australian economy so that Australia can emerge from the current stock market downturn with our economic fundamentals sound.

SPEECH.PARA: Why has the Opposition raised this matter of public importance? Why not just fade away after Question Time and say nothing? Because the reality is that this Government has been pursuing a very high risk economic strategy, and that risk has become even more evident and even greater today. This is no time for panic. It is no time for inciting a rush into dumping this matter on the Government. But it is a time for a hard-nosed appraisal and for the Government to recognise that its economic strategy has been wrong. It is a time for the bluff to end. It is a time for the bluster to end. It is a time for the gratuitous lecturing to other countries regarding their economies to end. Indeed, it is simply a time to face reality.

The Government, through its high risk economic strategy, has failed to protect Australia from adverse developments in the world economy. Every few days we have been reminded of the perilous state of the Australian economy-even more so today; although, as I say to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who has just entered the chamber, I am not dumping on the Government the fall on the stock market today. But for months the Opposition has been focusing on the slow pace of adjustment of the Government's policies to cope with our huge and growing foreign debt. We have been joined in our criticism not only by a number of commentators detached from this scene, but also by the Labor Government's own Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh, who raised the spectre of moving `further down the Argentinean road'. Now we are reminded once again of the consequences of the Government's failure to grasp the nettle on both fiscal and wages policies, of its failure to muster the political courage to rein in the public sector demand and to keep our costs of production in line with those of our overseas competitors.

As the Opposition has repeatedly said, the Government's economic policy leaves no margin for manoeuvre in the event of disruptions to world trade or a downturn in our terms of trade. It also leaves us in no position to cope with any fall-out from the current dramatic fall in prices on the stock exchanges around the world. As I said, this is no time to panic. But maybe it is a time for the Government to recognise that its strategy is wrong. It is just too risky. Take a line through last Friday. Only last Friday we received the September balance of payments figures. Australia's huge net foreign debt continued to grow at an unsustainable rate when the current account deficit deteriorated to $1.35 billion, nearly as large as the $1.39 billion recorded in July of this year. Overall, the balance of payments figures for September were bad news for Australia. They cast doubt on the pace of adjustment on external account and highlighted the incredibly risky strategy adopted by the Government, especially with regard to fiscal and wages policies.

Friday's figures indicate that the favourable result recorded for August, I regret to say, may well have been just a fluke. With a deficit of $681m for goods and services, Australia continued to borrow during September just to pay the interest on its net foreign debt, a foreign debt that under this Labor Government has quadrupled, putting us into a position of borrowing not just to try to retire debt-forget that; it is growing all the time-but simply to pay the interest on our net foreign debt. On the export side, exports of metal, metal manufactures, machinery and transport equipment contributed to the decline in total exports. The decrease in manufactured exports raised important questions about the contribution of the manufacturing sector to the adjustment process.

Most disturbing was the large increase in imports. I listened carefully to what the Treasurer had to say at Question Time. I agree with him that, if there is some importation of plant and equipment, then down the line there could be some benefit for us. That might have been the only good sign in the figures. But the reality is that if the Government had cut expenditure and public demand, we would have been able to bring in that equipment without an imbalance in our figures. In seasonally adjusted terms, imports in September were at their highest level for 12 months. Well, the Government failed to make substantial cuts in expenditure, leaving little room for expansion in private sector demand, including investment demand, without leading to an increase in imports. At the same time, the rapid increase in unit labour costs continues to erode our competitiveness. The poor outlook for productivity reinforces the fundamental failure of the Government's policy to generate sufficient net exports to service our huge and growing net foreign debt.

As I said on Friday, the Government continues to adopt a high risk strategy by not forcing the pace of adjustment on our domestic policies in the face of our high and growing external debt. Now, in the face of a bad news economic day for Australia, the Government must think again. It is time to take another serious look at investment, the engine for economic growth and for raising our productivity. It is time to look at the reasons why investment in plant and equipment has been in the doldrums in recent years. There has been plenty of investment on paper, but very little in plant and equipment. It has been flat while our foreign debt has grown rapidly. As I say, we have borrowed to finance public and private consumption. The only way to bring about a recovery in investment in plant and equipment is to cut taxes, to ensure that wages reflect productivity and to reduce interest rates. In all these areas the Government needs to review its policies to place Australia on a sound footing. The Government cannot go through what is transpiring in Australia today and simply allege that it has the greatest this or the greatest that in the history of Federation.

Australia's international credit rating was downgraded last year. That ought to have been the impetus for the Government to stop, look at its high risk strategy and make the necessary adjustments. It did not. We are not using today as an occasion for panic; we are using it as a further example of the need for a change in strategy. If we certainly needed to do it before today, in view of today's developments it becomes absolutely essential. The only way to bring about a sustainable and permanent cut in taxes is to reduce government expenditure, which is something the Government has proved incapable of doing.

It was interesting to note that while the Treasurer was overseas he made a number of observations about other countries' economies. In particular, he was very critical of the conduct of economic policy in the United States, including its fiscal and wages policies. Yet this Government has failed to bite the bullet and to bring about a significant reduction in government expenditure in real terms. This Government has failed to rein in public sector demand and has failed to provide enough room for a revival in private sector demand without risking a blowout in our imports. In addition, after the Treasurer criticised the United States for its wages policy, we should look at this Government's wages policy. This Government has failed to negotiate a wages policy which will maintain our international competitiveness. This year average weekly earnings are projected to rise for the third year in a row by 6.5 per cent. I find it difficult to comprehend how the Government can have the gall to criticise other countries' wages policies when we have such an abysmal record. Indeed, the Treasurer appears to be grasping at straws as it becomes more and more obvious that the Government's high risk economic strategy may not pay off.

I have said previously, but it is worth saying again, that if everything turned out well Australia might slip by. But as I said a few weeks ago in here, if one thing went wrong, the outlook could be very much worse. That was said before today, and how true it is. The two crucial areas that the Government has to address are its fiscal and wages policies. The Budget was, as we said last month, a missed opportunity, an illusion. The Government barely started to wind back expenditure. By further reducing public sector demand, we would have had more margin for manoeuvre in the private sector and in the demand for imports. The reality and the need is to reduce government expenditure and to release those resources, both labour and capital, from the public to the private sector. This will allow the movement of labour and capital from the non-tradable public sector to the tradable goods sector, thereby underpinning the adjustment effort and, of course, leading to an increase in domestic savings and therefore reducing the need for foreign borrowing to finance investment. These are the things that the Opposition today, without rancour and without wishing to beat up what is transpiring in the stock markets of the world, is saying to the Government. Its strategy is one of high risk. It must take note of where it is taking us.

The risks inherent in the Government's fiscal policy are undoubtedly matched by the risks in its wages policy. It simply has not been able to deliver a substantial cut in the rate of inflation. The topics of wage increases and, to a large extent, the rate of inflation have become increasingly politicised in Australia. The Government's wages policy has impeded the pace of adjustment on our current account and contributed significantly to our foreign debt problem. Rising unit labour costs have made our exports and import substitutes less competitive on world markets, and have therefore contributed to the current account deficit. Again, it is all very well for the Treasurer to say that real unit labour costs have declined and that net exports have improved in recent years. But with a more effective wages policy, with a system that limited wage increases to increases in productivity, net exports would have improved much more rapidly and our foreign debt would not be so large.

Let us hope that the Government shows a great deal more courage in negotiating wages for 1988-89 than it has shown in cutting expenditure in the 1987-88 Budget. In fact, it will get its chance tomorrow, with the national wage case hearing, to show some resolve in tackling, at this stage, what is one of our most important economic problems. It would be interesting to know whether the Treasurer will tell us today what the Government's attitude will be tomorrow; for much undoubtedly hangs on it.

If the Government had followed more prudent economic policies, if it had cut government expenditure and ensured that wages were set subject to market forces, we would have been in an infinitely stronger position; that is, lower domestic demand and a more competitive cost structure would have provided a fundamentally stronger balance of payments. We could have coped with any downturn in world economic activity. That is what I mean when I say that we have no margin for manoeuvre. Under the Government's economic strategy we have been operating on the knife's edge, sailing very close to the margin of error. We have relied too heavily on foreign investors to finance our slow pace of adjustment rather than taking the tough domestic economic policy decisions.

As I said at the outset, we may not be dumping it on the Government but we are saying, `Look at the nature of this high risk strategy that you are following'. The tragedy is that the strategy is one of high risk not only for the Government but also for Australia. It is Australians, and not just the wealthy-it is Australians, and not just the Government-who will suffer. Remember that in the past in this House the Treasurer alleged that the stock market was rising because of government policies. While I doubt whether at root the reverse is the case, nevertheless the Treasurer's own words from the past will have to be faced by him. However, today I have concentrated on the risk that he and the Government have imposed on Australia. The Budget of last month was a missed opportunity. But I trust opportunities will not be missed in the near future as the Government perseveres, as it has to date, with this high risk strategy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KEATING
TALKER.ROLE: Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather like living through a time warp; listening here to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), it is as though the last election campaign just weeks ago never occurred. With all the gall that he can muster and all the cheek that only a Liberal can muster, he talks about the pace of adjustment. Yet at the last election he and the Liberal Party of Australia proposed that the way we could respond to a fall in our terms of trade and our national income was with an unfunded tax cut, which would have blown out the Budget deficit and given a false lift to Australian living standards. That was not nine years ago; that was nine weeks ago. That was Opposition policy.

SPEECH.PARA: We remember how last year in debates in the House the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said, `You wait and see our tax policies'. He sat back smugly and said, `We will fight the election on tax. You wait and see our tax policies'. To paraphrase what he said, it was, `You wait and see the great grab bag of promises we will pull out right at the death to try to beat you over the electoral wire'. We did wait and what we saw was the Australian public reject for the first time ever the promise of a massive unfunded tax cut. The people knew it had nothing to it; they knew it would destroy our economy and the pace of economic adjustment. Here the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, just returned from another defeat with the most incredible economic policy that any major party has mounted in recent electoral history in this country, uses the incredible, indeed foolish, expression of a high risk strategy about a government which has taken the Budget deficit from 3 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) to zero in 18 months-something that no other government in the Western world has done and that no other government in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is within cooee of. That is simply a fact of life, not an argument. Around the world people respect the work this Government has done to make the rapid adjustments that Australia has made. But as late as this morning, on the front steps of Parliament House, the Leader of the Opposition said:
As far as the Opposition is concerned, our general approach of the last election of being in favour of smaller Government and lower taxation remains.

In other words, he is not recanting. He still wants to cut taxes. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, in his contribution, said that the Opposition believes it will cut taxes. On the one hand he says that we are not reducing the Budget deficit to surplus quickly enough but, on the other hand, he wants the luxury of saying, in the same contribution, how the Opposition would cut taxes and therefore lift the Budget deficit, without offsetting cuts to outlays. Of course, when the test came in the election campaign and members of the Opposition were asked how the Opposition would fund its reductions in revenue, and hence the increase in the deficit by cuts to outlays, they were mute. They had a handful of nothing. They spoke about the incentive effects and the supply side effects. When that express thing happened in the United States of America-unfunded tax cuts-it led to one of the major economic imbalances in the world, the United States Budget deficit. We have this mindless parroting that only Liberals can do about the Government's high risk strategy.

Last year we had domestic demand decreasing-in the negative; this year it is growing modestly. It is the third year of net export contribution to growth. We have made a $7 billion permanent structural change in the balance of payments coming from three years of net export contribution, a 10 per cent decline in real unit labour costs and a Budget deficit of nearly 5 per cent of GDP brought to zero, but the Deputy Leader of the Opposition calls it bluff and bluster. In other words, when left with the poison chalice of a Budget deficit of 5 per cent of GDP, a terms of trade slide, and with it a lift in the inflation rate, and massive cuts to outlays and to wages, what we have done is all bluff and bluster according to the honourable member for Kooyong. I simply say that if that is the best the Opposition can do it will remain as incredible as it is. It is a joke on Wall Street. It is a joke in Frankfurt. It is a joke in London. It does not matter where one goes, whenever the Opposition is mentioned there are smiles and nods. I am told, `Let's forget them; they're finished'. And the Opposition is finished while ever we have this sort of response.

The Leader of the Opposition is trying to get all his phrases and lines right and to get the strategy into his head, but one will notice from the contributions he makes that he is short on policy changes. Where would the Opposition cut outlays greater than this Government has? Where would it take what he calls the missed opportunity of the last Budget? Outlays were minus 2.5 per cent. It is the first consecutive fall in outlays in 35 years but the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has the stupid hide and gall to say it is bluff and bluster. However, the House will notice that there is no talk from him about where the Opposition would cut outlays.

We also have this nonsense about how the Opposition would tie wage increases to productivity. There was a 16 per cent increase in wages in its last year in government. There was no attempt at a wages policy. There was no attempt at dialogue with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). The rhetoric of the Opposition's election campaign was about union power. I can see the Opposition getting a great reception from the ACTU when it says to it, `Let's sit down to discuss wage increases tied only to productivity, but we will boot you to death every time we see you'. I mean, really!

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition says that the Government's strategies are bluff and bluster, that we are failing to protect Australia, that we lack the political courage to rein in public sector demand. We have public sector demand growing in the negative by the biggest factors in memory. We have the biggest cuts to outlays in memory-the only two consecutive falls in 35 years. In other words, he is saying, `If this is black, we will call it white; and if it's white, we will call it black'. That is not what the debate ought to be made of. If the Opposition wants to turn over a new leaf from its irresponsible policies of the election campaign it should say, `We wish to take more of the adjustment on wages or fiscal policy in these ways'. But it will not say that. It tries to undermine the Government's work by trying to suggest that the adjustments are not adequate or that the Government has fallen down on the job of making the economic adjustments in Australia when they are entirely ambitious.

Then I get this line about gratuitous advice to other governments. A hell of a lot of market sentiment shares my view this week-perhaps not last week-about the state of American fiscal policy. I would not want to be making policy the way Secretary Baker has had to make it, flying from Washington to Bonn as the markets start to slide. All that has happened because the United States trade accounts are not responding adequately. We have seen the market sentiment to that and the rise in interest rates. The fact is that the state of growth around the world and policy imbalances--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ours are exactly the same.

—The honourable member should listen in silence and have some courtesy. The policy imbalances between these major countries is of national moment to Australia. Our obligation is not to wander around the world saying, `There is a massive trade imbalance between the United States and Japan which could be worked out in Australia's disfavour by bilateral deals between the two countries or, perhaps more significantly, by choking off exports from Japan to the United States'. Should we say, `Oh, we are not going to comment on that. We will get chopped up on the way through, but we will not say anything; it is not our place to comment on it.'? Of course it is our place to comment on it. And the United States, like Australia, ought to be making the complementary shifts not just in the exchange rate, seeing the burden being taken on the exchange rate, but also in fiscal policy. Policy flexibility ought to be enhanced in Europe as well. Those are things which countries such as this one should say.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not prepared, unlike the honourable member for Kooyong, to be obsequious and fawning at international meetings. I go to such meetings to put Australia's view and Australia's national interest. The view that I put, when asked whether we can have exchange rate stability, was that we could not unless there was more policy flexibility and that without such flexibility the world of imbalances would end up with slower rates of growth over time, which must affect our terms of trade. That view which I put, which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition might have found a novel thing for me to have said last week, is not novel this week. People are saying that the adjustments are not moving quickly enough. The Secretary of the Treasury of the United States had to say yesterday, `I think the dollar ought to fall further'-in other words, `There is a greater need for adjustment of our trade accounts. We cannot get it out of fiscal policy, so I will tell the markets. I will fly to Bonn and check the story. I will tell the markets that the dollar ought to fall further'. That is precisely what I said; that if there was not an adjustment to fiscal policy the United States dollar would have to decline further.

It is no good the honourable member for Kooyong saying that I am making gratuitous comments about other countries. The Government is saying, `We are making the adjustments here; others should do the same; and if there is flexibility in terms of the policy prescriptions the world will be a better place and we will not see Japanese industry choked off by a cross-rate with the United States dollar which freezes Japan's exports'. The fact of the matter is that Japanese industry is adjusting so quickly that the view about now is that it will still prosper at a cross-rate of about 125 yen to the dollar. So even the exchange rate-the cross-rate between the United States dollar and the yen-will not be of sufficient magnitude as an instrument to change the trade balance without complementary domestic policy shifts such as those Australia has introduced.

It is just pointless for the honourable member for Kooyong to say, `It is political bluster' and to make such inane remarks as, `The Government is not making progress on inflation'. We have been through a 30 per cent price change with the depreciation from an induced collapse in the terms of trade. Of course there is an unavoidable rise in inflation. But, as we indicated in the Budget Papers, as a result of our wages policy, that will come back to about 6 per cent by the end of this financial year, whereas the United States is moving up to about 6 per cent. So that inflation differential between us and the rest of the world is closing very rapidly. Why should the honourable member suggest that it is not closing? Why try to say that black is white? The gap between us and the rest of the world is closing. The purpose of the Loans Bill 1987 is to make provision for the financing of the prospective Budget deficit in 1987-88 together with the associated prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. The Senate has returned the Bill to the House with amendments moved by the Opposition and supported by the Australian Democrats which effectively remove the Supply provisions from the legislation. As the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), who represents the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), indicated in his second reading speech, those Supply provisions were included to obviate the need for urgent passage each year for what is, in effect, a machinery financing measure and to provide continuity of borrowing authority in the hiatus between the expiry of one Loans Act on 30 June and the commencement of the next Loans Act. This continuity is desirable so as not to close off any possible advantageous borrowing opportunities in overseas markets during the first few months of the financial year.

It is unfortunate that Opposition speakers on this Bill have asserted falsely that the inclusion of a Supply provision in this legislation would impinge in some way on the Parliament's ability to debate financing of the Budget deficit, that the inclusion of a limit of defence expenditure appropriated in a Supply Bill is insidious and that the removal of the proposed Supply provisions would leave the Government with the same borrowing authority that it has had on previous occasions.

As a reading of the Bill and the associated explanatory memorandum or a rudimentary understanding of parliamentary procedures clearly demonstrates, these assertions are wrong. First, the inclusion of a Supply provision in an annual Loans Bill in no way detracts from Parliament's ability to debate or consider issues raised in that Bill. The Bill will remain an annual measure and in addition to Parliament having the ability to peruse its provisions for annual borrowing authority, the Supply provision would also be subject to scrutiny each year. In this context, the amount included in the Supply Bill for any one year for defence purposes will be subsumed by the larger amount included for defence in the subsequent Appropriation Bill for that year, the latter amount being the limit of authority permitted by the long-standing non-Supply provisions of part II of the annual Loans Act. Furthermore, with the size of the Budget deficit and the estimated borrowing requirements being announced in the Budget Speech and Papers, there is ample opportunity to consider these issues in the lengthy and wide-ranging debate allowed on the Budget.

Opposition members have made much of the assertion that removal of the Supply provisions in this Bill would merely restore the status quo. Nothing could be further from the truth. In recent years there have been two changes which have significantly reduced the borrowing authority under the dual Appropriation Acts which could have been drawn upon by governments in the Supply period. First, changed funding arrangements for expenditures on roads, involving the use of a trust fund set up specifically for that purpose, have eliminated the authority previously available under the former Roads Act; and, second, the inclusion of expenditure on housing assistance in the annual Appropriation Bills for 1987-88 demonstrates the volatility of borrowing authority available under the Housing Assistance Act. In current prices, the amount of borrowing authority that would have been available under these arrangements, had they not been changed, would have been of the order of $1,180m in 1987-88.

I turn now to the Loans Bill as a whole. Members of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have laid great store on the importance of this Bill. I agree that the legislation is important, but only in a machinery or accounting sense. I reiterate to the honourable members opposite that it does not provide for additional expenditure; it merely provides the legal authority to finance expenditure that has already been approved by the Parliament. Finally, as the shadow Treasurer acknowledged in 1985, the Opposition's amendments will not add one iota to the power or authority of Parliament. However, through restricting the flexibility of the Government to arrange borrowings at the most advantageous times, they will potentially add to the overall cost of the Commonwealth's borrowings. Any such increases can be clearly laid at the feet of the Opposition and the Democrats. Any reading of the Senate debate and the contributions that were made to that debate by Senator Stone will show that those contributions and the supporting statements of the Leader of the Australian Democrats were an exercise in parliamentary humbug of the most extreme kind. They have done neither themselves nor the Senate any honour. In view of the inflexible and obstructionist behaviour of the Opposition and the Democrats and the need to get the Loans Bill into place quickly for this financial year, the Government has no option but to accept these amendments.
