TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987 seeks to amend the Australian Land Transport Act by reducing the amount of excise collected through the Australian land transport program trust fund in order to hold total Federal road finance at $1,245m for 1987-88. This is the fourth year in a row that expenditure on roads has been held at that level. This Bill gives effect to an announcement in the May statement.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not oppose the Bill. However, we on this side of the House condemn the Government for its lack of commitment to important spending on infrastructure. It is a major fault of this Government that it has continued to ignore cries from a very significant number of Australians of all political persuasions for government to get out of their lives, to stop interfering with them in every conceivable way and to stop spending their money. The failings of big government are now well recognised throughout the world yet this Government refuses to budge on reducing the size of its expenditures. Taxes should be spent on things which only a central government can do and only then on things that a central government can do well, such as on the organisation of large infrastructure developments like appropriate road and transport systems. Until this Government realises that there is not an endless amount of money which can be drawn from the taxpayer to support its bankrupt view of the economy, important and easily identified infrastructure spending, such as that embodied in the Australian land transport program, will remain the target for the Government's Expenditure Review Committee. It does not seem to make any difference to the Government that huge savings could be made by its rationalising ongoing commitments.

Further, there are, for example, ongoing commitments to Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd. I remind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that Qantas alone will need $400m over the next five years and Australian Airlines will need several hundred million dollars quickly if it is to re-equip its fleet and compete effectively with the other domestic airline. Qantas and Australian Airlines will need this amount of money, and the Government was not even honest enough in its recent announcement about airline deregulation to state its real intention of steamrolling its left wing at next year's Australian Labor Party Conference so that it can facilitate the sale of Australian Airlines. What is needed in order to prevent these large ongoing commitments of some $400m for Qantas and several hundred million dollars for Australian Airlines is for those bodies to be privatised. We in the Opposition would transfer ownership of Australian Airlines from the public sector to the private sector and sell a minority interest in Qantas. If this were done-and I hope that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), will take note of this-the Government would not have to find these large amounts of money for these bodies and therefore would have more funds for such important matters as support for Australia's infrastructure.

Instead, the Government will continue to make cuts such as those made in this Bill rather than face the real issues of government expenditure. This Government is so intent on regulating every aspect of our lives that it has involved itself in an incredible array of activities in which it need have no involvement. These activities all cost money-taxpayers; money and, most of the time, money from which the taxpayer sees absolutely no return. Unless the Government is prepared to reappraise the way it spends money, Australia's infrastructure will fall down around our ears. Already, sealed country roads in every State are being torn up and returned to gravel because there is insufficient money in the system for their maintenance and refurbishment. Although the States and local government have their part to play, the specific trend of road funding since this Government was first elected in 1983 is a serious degradation of the role of the Commonwealth and represents cuts in road spending in real terms.

There are things which a Federal Government can do, and road funding is one of them. If the Government refuses to recognise this responsibility, as it has failed to recognise it in the past four years, there is little doubt that a great national infrastructure asset which has been built up over many years will be seriously damaged. I welcome the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) to the chamber so that he can listen to me and hear about the way in which his Government has let down the Australian people by its failure to maintain expenditure on roads in real terms over the past four years. This Bill is a further indication that this Government will continue to refuse to honour its responsibilities. Effectively, this Bill will reduce the excise by 0.723c per litre as from 1 July 1987 to 3.241c a litre. To add insult to this injury, revenue generated by the balance of the excise before these amendments come into force on 1 July will be paid out of the Australian Land Transport Trust Fund into Consolidated Revenue. On top of this, any investment income which accrues from these moneys while they are held in the Trust Fund will also be paid into Consolidated Revenue. In addition, $1m will be taken out of the Australian land transport program excise to pay for the cost of administering this scheme.

We in the coalition accept the principle of cost recovery or user pays, but as is the case with the aviation industry, road freight and many other areas, that cost recovery must be fair and equitable. In effect, as a result of what the Government is proposing in this Bill, spending on roads will be reduced by a further $1m-from $1,245m last year to $1,244m in 1987-88. This is a further erosion of spending on roads not only in dollar terms but also in real terms. All this amounts to an assault on road funding, with the result that Federal road financing in Australia will sink to its lowest level in real terms for many years, with road funding measured as a percentage of total Commonwealth Government outlays.
The previous Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, whose reputation after the Amann affair is in tatters, said when introducing the original Bill into the House in 1985:

The Bill now before the House will be the foundation upon which our overall approach to transport will be based. It provides a use related basis for determining Federal expenditure on land transport systems. Furthermore, the arrangements incorporate an automatic adjustment to match future inflationary movements as measured by the consumer price index.
Let me repeat what the Minister said:
. . . the arrangements incorporate an automatic adjustment to match future inflationary movements as measured by the consumer price index.
He continued:

It guarantees the continuity of the greatest road building program in Australia's history, which has been progressively implemented during our two years of government. Together with the Australian bicentennial roads development program, Federal expenditure on roads will total $1,245m in 1985-86.
Later he stated:

The Bill establishes a trust fund which will operate on a similar basis to the ABRD Trust Fund. It provides that an indexed share of the existing excise charge on motor spirit and diesel fuel will be paid into the ALTP Trust Fund based on collections from 1 July 1985 until 30 June 1990.
The clear implication was that money for roads from this program would be indexed according to inflation from 1 July 1985 until 30 June 1990. Minister Morris further stated in 1985:

Specifically, in this Bill we have the fulfilment of this Government's long-standing policy commitment to the improvement of our nation's road system-a system which under conservative governments was starved of essential investment funds.

Let us note what the Minister was saying. He was first saying that there would be an automatic adjustment to the moneys appropriated for use on roads. He used the word `indexed' to imply very strongly that the automatic adjustment would be indexed to inflation, and talked about the Government's long-standing policy commitment to the improvement of our nation's road system. Well, if ever a statement was made in this House that ignored so many facts and completely bypassed the Government's intention, it was that one. Four years have gone by and the magical indexation of the Australian land transport program fuel excise remains as elusive as ever.

The former Minister gloatingly told this House in 1985 that indexation of this amount would solve all the road financing problems for ever and a day. Unfortunately, it was unable to solve the biggest problem which Australia continues to face, and that is the misleading of the Australian people by this Government. This Bill, like others before it, will wind back the excise to be collected so that the effect of automatic indexation will be eliminated. It is exactly as though we had no indexation at all. The Government commits itself to automatic indexation of fuel excise and then proceeds to wind back the amount of that excise as though indexation did not exist-an extra tax, because the Government collects the money for other purposes and earns interest on it. The amount that is indexed is set aside as an extra tax and taken into Consolidated Revenue. The absence of this hypocritical farce would certainly make it easier for State and local governments trying to plan their road construction programs around the vagaries of this Federal Government's decreasing contribution to road financing.

This will be the fourth year in a row that Federal Government road funding has stayed at the same figure in dollar terms-$1,245m. That is setting aside the fact that this year the Government intends, by virtue of moving the administration of the program from the Department to funds taken from the program, to reduce the amount by a further $1m to $1,244m. So not only has the program failed to keep up with inflation, which has been eating away at the $1,245m figure by about 9 per cent per year, but also the Government is reducing the amount in dollar terms by $1m from $1,245m to $1,244m.

TALK.START.PARA: —And to build a road costs more than 9 per cent.

—I appreciate the contribution from my friend and colleague. He points out quite rightly that every year this program has been maintained in dollar terms at $1,245m, in real terms it has been effectively worth 9 per cent less. Not only that, but 9 per cent compounded over a four-year period means that spending on roads in real terms has dropped by over 40 per cent.
—Nonsense.

—Can the honourable member not do the mathematics? A 9 per cent reduction compounded over four year means a real reduction of 40 per cent. The honourable member will have his opportunity to rebut that. He can be assured that the Australian people can do the multiplication. They know that over the last four years the Government's contribution to roads around Australia in real terms has fallen by over 40 per cent.
—What was your contribution when you were in government?

—I am talking about this Government's contribution. Its contribution over a four-year period, despite its undertaking to index the funds for roads, has been a drop in real terms of over 40 per cent. What a magnificent achievement for the present Minister to feel good about-a reduction in road funding of more than 40 per cent from the Federal Government! That is hardly an example of appropriate spending priorities or of sensible government.

SPEECH.PARA: For all the claims this Government has made about how good its record on road funding is, for all the self-congratulation in which the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) is indulging, and for all the road and bridge opening which the media has had to put up with-some roads have been opened twice; on one end of the road and then on the other-the real record of this Government can be seen by looking at road finance expressed as a percentage of total government outlays. There are plenty of other ways of looking at the figures. All of them show the Government in a very bad light, but this figure, in particular, highlights the decreasing importance which this Government has placed on road funding.

In the last year of the coalition Government, 1982-83, which was the first year in which the coalition-introduced Australian bicentennial road development program had any effect, road funding accounted for 2.12 per cent of total government outlays. The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and the honourable member for Aston would do well to write that figure down. I should add that it was thanks to my colleague the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), who was the Minister at the time, that the Australian bicentennial road development program was introduced. Regardless of the vacuous claims Labor loves to make about how it introduced the scheme, when the honourable member for Gwydir introduced the scheme in the Parliament in 1982, members of the present Government sat here and complained wildly about it.

This Government has been responsible for one of the greatest rip-offs in road funding ever. That is said mindful of how effective this Government has been at creating this rip-off. By collecting only 2c a litre for the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund levy as part of the general excise collection, the Government has effectively allowed itself to collect the indexed portion of the excise. By the end of the extended program, as a result of the Government collecting the indexed portion of the excise, it will have siphoned over $1 billion straight into Consolidated Revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The poor old motorist.

—Although it may be argued that the indexed portion of the money should go to roads, it is obvious that the Government is quite happy to continue to corrupt the scheme and pocket the difference between the money raised by the 2c levy and the indexed portion of the excise.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only in the area of cutbacks that this Government is doing the wrong thing. It is also ripping off the taxpayer and, in this case, as my friend the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) says, the motorist, to prop up its big-spending social welfare programs which it is absolutely terrified of cutting because it knows that buying votes is the only way from now on that it will stay in office. So, for my attentive audience from Capricornia and Aston, I come back to a comparison between what the coalition did in its last year of office and what this Government has done. I compare the 2.12 per cent of Commonwealth outlays spent on roads in that year, 1982-83, to the current level, less than 1.6 per cent of outlays, which Labor will spend on roads this year. These figures tell the real story.

TALK.START.PARA: —Reduction.

—The ratio of total outlays on roads to total government expenditure is down from 2.1 per cent, which it was in 1982-83, to 1.6 per cent in the current year. That is what is happening to road programs under Labor. This Bill will take a further $1m away from roads to pay for the bureaucrats who administer the Australian Land Transport Fund. According to the Minister's second reading speech, the cost of administering the program is $1m-not $999,000, but $1m. That is the cost-a very convenient round number. When talking about the amount of administrative expenses, he said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: This will be limited to $1m in 1987-88 . . .

I leave everybody to use their imagination and decide what that will mean for next year. It is a clear indication that the Government intends next year to cut further the amount to be spent on roads. Once we take away all the false claims and self-congratulatory nonsense, what has this Government done for road financing? It has not done a single, solitary thing. It has sat on its hands since 1983 and allowed road funding to be eaten away by the high level of inflation which, I might say, has been caused by its economic policies. They have created record levels of inflation compared with those of our major trading competitors. The fact is they are almost twice those of our competitors. The Government has made no attempt to adjust its road funding for the inflation factor which it created by its economic policies. The figure has been the same for four years-$1,250m. No one, except those in this Government, would have the audacity to do such a thing, while flying around the countryside claiming to be the saviours of Australia's roads. Nothing could be further from the truth.

The Government is also misleading the public when it says that the financial implication in this Bill is a saving to the Government of $166m in 1987-88. This is like all of the figuring of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). It is intended to mislead and to paint a rosy picture of the responsible way in which the Government is handling its financial problems. But the truth of the matter is far from that. The truth is that of the $166m, which the Government says it will save by cutting road funding-which is down from $180m as expressed in the Forward Estimates-$67.6m will be saved, and I underline the word `saved', by running down the reserves of the trust funds established for these programs. The Australian Land Transport Program Trust Fund will be run down from $23.6m to zero, and the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund will be run down from $58.4m to $19.5m; a run down of $38.9m. The trust funds are being run down, one to zero and one by two-thirds, so that the Government can finance its road program in the current year. In cutting the Forward Estimates, by simply negating the effect of indexation on the Australian land transport program excise, the Government is cutting funds that never existed in the first place. The money that was talked about in the Forward Estimates simply did not exist. The fact that the Government is running down its trust funds would make everybody wonder what it intends to do next year. Where will the money come from next year if it is running down the trust funds this year? It has run the funds down by $67.6m in the current year and it will have only $19.5m left, so where will the extra $50m-odd come from next year? I can see the eyebrows going up on some of my friends in the National Party of Australia, who are concerned about roads in their electorate, as they wonder where the $50m will come from next year.

Another example of the illusory accounting of the Treasurer is the Government's decision to hold funding at the same level in dollar terms as it has for the last four years. Who will that affect? It will affect those who use roads in Australia, and that means everybody. This Government's inability to come to grips with the fact that spending on essential infrastructure is more important than money for Builders Labourers Federation muralists and storytellers, and even more important than funds to be set aside for the design of a women's surf board, indicates the increasingly compromised position of the Party which is now the Government of this country. It does not even know who is running Australia's foreign policy. We read in this morning's newspapers that the waterfront unions seem to be.

Spending on roads and other infrastructure is essential if Australia is to return to being an efficient and effective producer and exporter and is to help extract itself from its present economic malaise. It is time that this Government stopped resting on the achievements and initiatives of the previous coalition Government in road funding, and actually contributed something rather than continually identify road funding as an easy mark when the Treasurer finds that his sums are wrong again and that he has to make Budget cuts.

In Queensland there are still signs put up by the Queensland Government along the national highways, which have been funded totally by the Commonwealth and with not 1c provided by the Queensland Government, saying, `Look what we have done'; the Queensland Government takes the credit. I sent a submission to the Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Racing, Russ Hinze, and again he came back with the typical response: `We can only do something about it if the Federal Government gives us more money'. How pathetic for a Minister of the Crown in Queensland to take such an inhumane attitude to such an important issue as road safety. Obviously, he wanted to duck his responsibility and his Government's responsibilty. Obviously, he wanted to hide away, walk away from and refuse to acknowledge the dangers on central Queensland roads. The Queensland Government has tried desperately to play down the issue.

I think we can take the example in Queensland and use it across Australia. I am calling for an all out Australia-wide campaign to alleviate the danger spots. Blind Charlie can see what is wrong with the price of petrol in Canberra. Anyway, in Darwin it was 44.5c a litre.

Listen to these figures for December 1986. In Sydney the average price was 54.9c. People forget these prices. It is like a sore on one's hand: once it has healed one forgets about it. But the people of Australia are being conned. We hear the Government talk about road improvements, but the money is coming from the taxpayers' pockets. It is not a State thing or a Federal thing; it is coming from their pockets in the price of petrol. I feel sorry for the people of Australia at the moment because many of them are being conned with this petrol pricing. People may buy a new car at an average cost of about $15,000 or a new truck-they have also gone up to billyo-and every time they use those vehicles it costs those people big dough for every kilometre they go. We talk about the poor and the needy. Consider, for example, a person who lives in Bridgewater in Hobart. Regrettably, the person on the lowest end of the scale has the oldest car. Sometimes that car is more important to such a person than his house, his children, his wife or whatever. A car is important to these people. They have to use it for their work, and because of the necessities imposed by a stringent budget it becomes a place of entertainment for them, too; they use the car of a weekend. So in Hobart, if a car is doing 20 miles to the gallon, it is costing $3 to go 20 miles, to use the old imperial system. These increases have taken people by storm-$3 to go 20 miles. Every mile these people go they are paying for the roads. Every mile that truck drivers travel they are paying for the roads also. They must get sick of the sight of signs saying `This is a Federal funded road' or `This is a State funded road'. I say to the honourable member for Bass: You have never heard me get involved with roads as a political ploy. You have never heard me say, `Look I have got that road'.

—But honourable members never hear me saying about roads, `I got that road'. I did not get any roads; the taxpayers of my electorate are the ones who get any such roads. It is a sad and sorry world, if honourable members do not mind my saying so. The petroleum industry is a sad and sorry industry. All of us here should be ashamed of it. TALK.START.PARA: —A subsidy?

That is one of the reasons why many people are starting to wake up and say, `What is going on with this? We are paying out in the roads, fine. We are paying out in taxes, fine. —You're right.

—I am right and the honourable member for Bass knows it. What has been happening in Tasmania for years, because of the small market there in comparison with Melbourne and Sydney, is wrong. The Federal MP for Deakin, Mr Julian Beale, went further than Mr Howard, arguing that the next Liberal government should cut $3 billion from the deficit and take $3 billion from other programs in its first Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the comments of the honourable member for Deakin in this debate this afternoon. He claimed that since the election of the Hawke Government there had been a `serious degradation of road funding'. The honourable member for Deakin has made another arithmetical error. In the five Hawke Budgets road funding has been 24 per cent higher in real terms than it was in the last five Fraser-Howard Budgets. I see the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) is in the chamber and if he disputes those figures I challenge him to respond when he makes his contribution. In the five Hawke Budgets we have spent 24 per cent more in real terms on road funding than the Liberals and Nationals allocated in the last five Fraser-Howard years.

I will simply outline some areas-some would say concrete examples-of where that road funding is producing improvements for road users throughout Australia. The national highways program dates from 1974 when the then Minister for Transport, the Hon. Charlie Jones, the then member for Newcastle, proclaimed our current national highway system. At the moment there are 16,000 kilometres of national highways throughout Australia and they link all capital cities plus a number of major developed areas. In 1974, when the national highways program began, 26 per cent of that area was unsealed and that was a great disgrace to Australia. Some 66 per cent of our national highways was less than 22 feet wide. By late next year, through the efforts of the Federal Government, more than $5,000m will have been spent on our national highways, and that is something of which all of us can be very proud. My area of Dobell, which covers the northern half of the central coast of New South Wales, has benefited greatly by that spending on the national highways program.

Anyone who has driven from Sydney north through the central coast or to Newcastle will know that late last year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) opened the Moonie Moonie Bridge which has cut a very substantial amount off the travelling time between Sydney and the central coast and Sydney and Newcastle. In addition, on 20 September this year the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) officially opened the latest extension to the national highway system in my electorate. That section from Wallara Creek to Morisset was carried out in conjunction with the very able New South Wales Minister for Roads, Laurie Brereton.

A great deal of work is still going on on the national highway system. Anyone who drives to Sydney from the north these days is aware that a great deal of effort and money is being spent on roadworks on the eastern side of the railway line. By, I think, early 1989 people will be able to travel by freeway from Pearces Corner at Hornsby all the way through to Freemans Waterholes and further north. Not only does this save our economy money by allowing trucks and cars to travel more quickly on better roads but we should not forget that many lives are saved because people no longer have to travel on narrow and dangerous roads.

It is very important that this national Parliament continue to allocate very large sums of money for additions to the national highway system and to ensure that the current national highway system is properly maintained. Other members might be better aware of the money that we have spent on the Hume Highway and roads into and out of Canberra. My friends who have travelled from Sydney to Melbourne in recent years are often staggered by the great efforts and achievements that have already been made on the Hume Highway.

The last few comments I wish to make in this debate concern first of all the Government's decision to extend the Australian bicentennial road development program for a further five years. I believe that the majority of Australians are prepared to pay the 2c per litre levy on the one simple condition that those funds are spent on road construction and maintenance. The bicentennial road development program has been a great success and probably a large number of Australians are alive today only because we have improved the quality and safety of our roads. I have great pleasure in supporting the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the House that in 1975-76 total revenue from fuel was $968m. The total road funds spent by the Commonwealth were $434m. So total road funds, as a percentage of excise, were 61.6 per cent. Total road funds spent out of the total fuel revenue were 44.8 per cent. So 10 or 11 years ago-in 1975-76-nearly half of total road funds were being spent on roads. I think it is appropriate to look at what has changed since then. Total revenue from fuel has grown from $968m in 1975-76 to $6,960m in 1986-87, an incredible growth for which the motorist is paying. It is worth while examining the amount of money which is being spent on roads. Of that $6,960m spent in 1986-87 only $1,171m was actually spent on roads by the Commonwealth or, as a percentage of excise, only 20.7 per cent. Compare that with the 61.6 per cent of excise which was spent in 1975-76. As a percentage of total road funds, fuel revenue was 16.8 per cent. I said at the outset that I wanted to speak specifically about the Pacific Highway because of the great interest I have in it as if affects my electorate in particular and the whole of Australia. The volume of traffic on the Pacific Highway is now the greatest of that anywhere in this country. What I have been seeking to do ever since I was elected to this Parliament is to sow the seeds of a commitment to the Pacific Highway becoming a four-lane, dual carriageway, divided highway for its total length, not just for the freeway between Sydney and Newcastle but also from Hexham up to the Queensland border, through all of those wonderful towns which dot the seats of the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) and the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt). We have on the north coast of New South Wales in those four seats held by the National Party of Australia, which are all well served--

TALK.START.PARA: —Top members, including you.

—I thank the honourable member. This area includes the best part of Australia. I know it is common for people to come here and say, `My electorate is the best part of Australia'. But even the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has said that the mid-north coast of New South Wales has the optimum climate for the human animal. This is why growth has been so spectacular. Once all the figures are out from the recent census it will be seen that the growth on the north coast of New South Wales has been absolutely sensational. In fact, the preliminary figures are out and they show that this area has the highest growth rate of anywhere in Australia. This indicates the need for that major artery, the Pacific Highway, to be upgraded even further. I would be remiss if I did not, at this point, acknowledge most sincerely and warmly the tremendous contribution made to the work on the Pacific Highway by my colleagues the honourable member for Page-he was formerly the honourable member for Cowper-the honourable member for Lyne, the honourable member for Richmond and the various members of the State Parliament from that part of New South Wales. A great deal has been done to the highway and many improvements have been made. But a great deal more needs to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly concerned by the most recent figures to hand from the National Roads and Motorists Association (NRMA) which show that in driving north from Hexham to the Queensland border it is illegal to overtake on 41 per cent of the highway because of double lines. Frankly, it is unsafe to overtake on about 50 per cent of the highway. On 41 per cent one cannot overtake because of the double lines and on close to an extra 10 per cent it is, in reality, unsafe to overtake. As I drive up and down the Pacific Highway, I notice that the New South Wales Department of Main Roads is continually using more paint and creating more double lines, thus restricting even further the amount of highway available for overtaking. Even though so much tremendous work has been undertaken by other honourable members-and I note that the honourable member for Page, of whom I spoke earlier, has come into the chamber-there is still an enormous safety problem on that highway because on more than 50 per cent of it, it is illegal or unsafe to overtake while one is going north.

The highway accident statistics-I will not bore the House with them at the moment-available in this country, the United States of America and elsewhere demonstrate quite clearly that where there is a dual-carriageway, a divided road, the accident rate goes down dramatically. One only has to look at the figures for the Hume Highway to see that this is the case. It is proper to put on record that the Pacific Highway, to most people's surprise, is not part of the national highway system. Everywhere one goes on the Pacific Highway one sees the signs which say `Highway 1'-as well as the signs which praise Mr Brereton for the work that the New South Wales Government is doing with Commonwealth money, and there are more signs of that nature than any other. People think that because the highway is marked `Highway 1' it is part of the national highway system. But, of course, it is not. In reality the Pacific Highway is New South Wales State Highway No. 10. On a national level, it is not classified as a highway at all; it is a rural arterial road. Frankly, I do not really care what it is called. I know and fully understand, as some people do not, that the national highway system is a set system which was the result of an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. It cannot be changed and, even if it were, the formula is set. If the Pacific Highway were to be made a national highway it would actually receive less money than it is receiving now.

I say to the House and to the Minister that we need on a Federal level, and also, of course, on a State level, a commitment to the concept of turning the Pacific Highway into a four-lane, dual carriageway, divided highway. This must come eventually. The road usage is increasing enormously. In the middle of last year the NRMA established 18 points on the highway between Hexham and the Queensland border where the volume of highway traffic was being measured. At all of those 18 points there are already traffic volumes which justify having a four-lane, dual carriageway, divided highway. Therefore, I want to emphasise that, particularly in the current economic climate, we are not looking for an incredible injection of funds overnight. That would be unreasonable and not very sensible. But I have no hesitation whatsoever in saying to this Parliament and to the New South Wales Parliament-and, of course, to the Queensland Parliament because the Pacific Highway extends into Queensland, through Brisbane-that there must be a commitment to getting there eventually, so that when we undertake planning we plan to have a four-lane, dual carriageway, divided highway. Thus, when it does come about it will be done at the least cost to society and the community.

Tourism is of vital importance to the north coast of New South Wales and, of course, to Australia. We hear the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) in this chamber and elsewhere making the point about the value of tourism to this economy. I and every member who represents those areas on the north coast of New South Wales are fully aware of the value of tourism to Australia and to the people we represent. If we do not have a road that will adequately satisfy the needs of the people we do not have the wherewithal to transport those people to those areas. A survey conducted by the University of New England for the Coffs Harbour tourist organisation a couple of years ago identified the fact that some 92 per cent of respondents to the survey travelled in their own vehicles. When we are discussing the growth of the Pacific Highway, and the need to improve it and turn it into a four-lane, divided highway, we are looking at a whole range of features. We are looking at the commercial growth of the area and at satisfying the commercial growth and needs of Sydney and Brisbane as well. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that even where the road has been improved drivers are still only as fast as the slowest caravan, the slowest house being transported, the slowest semitrailer or even the slowest swimming pool being transported, because they all use this highway. Economically it is important that transport should be able to flow freely along that major network.

Before I conclude I would like to refer to the road safety requirements. I would like to put on the record the traffic accident levels comparing the Pacific, the Hume and the New England highways. I am looking at the period from 1979 to 1985. The number of fatal crashes on the Pacific Highway in that period was 585 or 84 a year. On the Hume Highway there were 331 or 47 a year. Of course, the Hume Highway's traffic accident record has improved dramatically because of the dual carriageway highway. On the New England Highway there were 161 or 23 fatal crashes a year. On a per annum average over that period from 1979 to 1985 the average is 84 for the Pacific, 47 for the Hume and only 23 for the New England, where the traffic volume is way down. The number of fatalities was 698 on the Pacific, 420 on the Hume and 199 on the New England. That is over the whole period. The annual average was 100 for the Pacific, 60 for the Hume and 28 for the New England. This means that the funding provided for the Hume Highway and for the New England Highway has saved Australian lives. Additional funding should be provided, come hell or high water, as soon as possible to save other Australian lives on the Pacific Highway. One also has to consider injury crashes, as an annual average, which, for the Pacific Highway, amount to 1,376; for the Hume Highway, 803; and for the New England Highway, only 324. In that period one is looking at total crashes for the Pacific Highway amounting to 24,406 or 3,487 a year; for the Hume Highway, 14,949 or 2,136 a year; and for the New England Highway 5,441 or 777 a year.

In terms of funding to upgrade the road which serves the most settled parts of Australia, the road with the greatest usage, I ask honourable members: What is more important, the money or the people? In reality, when one looks at the matter logically and sensibly-I do not have time to go into it in great detail-the costs of the deaths, the costs of the accidents, the costs to people who are now quadriplegic or paraplegic, the ongoing costs of treating so many people for decades, and indeed the costs in relation to property are amazing. I believe that over a period of a year the cost of upgrading the Pacific Highway to prepare it for the twenty-first century will be, in the long term, a saving over the cost of the pain, the suffering, the damage and the injuries.

I know that constraints face the Government and indeed the whole of Australia. When I spoke on this topic on an earlier occasion, a previous Minister accused me of having double standards. He said that on the one hand I was asking for more money and on the other hand suggesting cuts in spending. The reality is that in the current economic climate there are areas in which we must cut government expenditure and areas in which we must spend. We all have our priorities. I admit that many of the priorities of our colleagues on the Government benches are reasonable and proper, but it is not good enough just to make idle speeches on road safety or merely to say, `We must cut down on accidents'. We must stop children being run over and must put our money where our mouth is.

The time to make a start is now. I repeat that I do not suggest that this can happen overnight. We are looking at a 20-year project. But all I ask is that we make a decision nationally at Commonwealth and State level to say, `This is the way to go, this is what must happen for the benefit of all Australians. This is what must be done to cut down the numbers of deaths and injuries that affect so many of our fellow countrymen'. We must make a decision to make this happen when the money is available. We need the commitment so that the Pacific Highway can eventually serve Australia as it should.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill seeks to amend the Australian Land Transport Act, in the main to alter the excise rate, although there are a couple of other amendments in the Bill allowing for the expenditure of $1,250m on roads. Anyone who examines the record of this Government on road funding and our land transport program introduced under the previous Minister, the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris), a program which has continued to be supported by the Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), knows that the program has nationwide support, even though it does not enjoy the support of our colleagues on the Opposition benches. The program has attempted to put forward long term funding, even though it is adjusted on an annual basis, with some surety to the recipients of the funds as to the levels of road funding that may be available into the future. Even though this year the program represents a reduction in real terms, it has provided some surety as to the level of funding in the past few years.

SPEECH.PARA: Although we all regret the fact that from time to time it is necessary to reduce funds by not providing for an increase on previous years fundings because of financial constraints, we must still bear in mind the overall picture. In the tight financial constraints of the Budget-and the Government has received widespread support for its Budget outcomes-it was clear that every area of government activity would be subjected to some form of constraint. Road funding has been a victim, as have most other areas.

Having heard some of the points raised by Opposition members, particularly those raised by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), one must look at the Opposition's credibility. As was pointed out by the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), not so long ago the honourable member for Deakin advocated that if the coalition gained power it would provide no funds at all for road funding from the Federal Government to State or local governments. He then had the hide to bleat in this House that a sum of $1,250m is not enough and that the Government should be criticised for reducing the funds by a small percentage compared with last year. But if a coalition government had been elected in July-thank goodness it was not-it would have been presenting a Budget in which no funds would have been spent on roads; there would have been not just cuts, but no funds for roads. Opposition members criticise the Government for not spending enough when it has allocated $1,250m, but those same Opposition members openly admit that if they had attained government they would not spend anything like $1,250m, and indeed would spend nothing on roads.

Anybody who doubts that statement should examine the record of the coalition Government to see whether it had a commitment to roads. During the period of the coalition Government, from 1976-77 to 1981-82, each financial year, year by year, it reduced in real terms the allocation of funds to roads. By 1981-82 that Government had dropped the amount spent on roads in real terms to just over $1,000m. It dropped the allocation from an all time high during the Whitlam period in real terms down to a level in today's terms of $1,000m in 1981-82. In every year from 1976-77 to 1981-82 that Government reduced the amount of funds in real terms. Thankfully, that Government was put out of office and the Australian Labor Party came in.

As soon as Labor came to office we significantly lifted road funding again and recognised such funding as a priority. We saw the damage inflicted by the Opposition because of the reduction in road funding and immediately lifted it to an all time high level of funding in real terms. The current level of funding of $1,250m in real terms is still nearly $200m more than the lowest level achieved by the Fraser Government in 1981-82. Our record is one of which we should be proud. There is no question that the amount of funds we put in has helped significantly in the roads programs of the last four years. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) said that more funds were required to meet his particular interest, that is, roads in his electorate. It is ironic that Opposition members take part in these debates and express the view that more government money should be spent on roads in their areas and that more money should be spent on local government, and on this and that. Opposition members sit back and allow their spokespeople on the front bench and their Leader to stand up and say, `There will not be more money. There will be less money. We are going to cut this program and that program. There will be nothing for you at all'.

In the May statement the Government announced that the 2c per litre surcharge for the Australian bicentennial road development (ABRD) program will be continued for the next five years. That was an important announcement. In the community, the States, local government and the road construction industry there was a great deal of uncertainty about what was going to happen with road funding in general. It was an important decision for the Government-and I am glad that we made it-to continue the levy and the program for the five years following 1988. It has removed doubts from the minds of people concerned about road construction and the provisioning of roads as to what sort of levels may exist after next year.

I am not too sure whether people would be happy with what the Opposition is doing. Opposition members are not only talking about no funds at all, but also they are not giving any commitment towards road funding or the ABRD program. I do not intend to talk at great length about funding in general. Most of the points that we have made have been very clear. The Federal Government only has certain responsibilities in road funding, primarily for national roads, although some of the funds it provides supplement arterial and local road construction within States.

Some groups in the community like to exploit opportunities to politicise this sort of debate. During the last election the local council in my area decided that it would attempt to support some of its Liberal candidates by attacking the Government's record on road funding. During the election campaign the council erected road signs in areas where roads needed work done on them pointing out that they were an example of people's taxes not being put to work. A number of Federal members in the area criticised the council at the time for politicising the debate. We pointed out that during the period of the Fraser Government the council had been unconcerned about the continual reduction in road funding. It did not seem to find it a problem during the seven Fraser years. But during the period it had the highest level of road funding in real terms ever, during the four years of this Government, it was prepared to embark upon a campaign saying that it had not had enough.

It was of great interest to me subsequently to find out that not only had we significantly lifted the level of funding to the city of Knox-prior to our coming to office it was receiving slightly over one per cent of road funding in Victoria-to a figure in excess of 2 per cent but also 6that the council had been unable to spend most of the money it had received over the last five years. As an example of how much money it was getting, in 1982-83, which was the last year of the Fraser Government, it got $600,000 for road funding under the ABRD program. In 1986-87, the amount was $2.9m, after having been at a high, in 1985-86, of $3.6m. During the period 1982-83 to 1986-87, the council had received a total of slightly under $10m for road funding but had been able to spend only about $4.6m. So the council was complaining about not having enough funds and about not being able to fix the roads, but in reality it had been unable to spend the money allocated to it for road funding. If that is not hypocrisy of the greatest order, I do not know what is.

I think the council will probably live to regret the fact that it decided to embark on such a campaign. We have certainly exploited some of the areas in which it has failed to act. The greatest tragedy is that it failed to act when the greatest damage was being done, that is, during the period of the Fraser Government, when funds were systematically reduced, year by year, and road construction was set back to a great degree. As I have said, our program has lifted funds to the extent that our record, over any four-year or five-year period, shows that we have probably done 20 per cent better, or more, than the Fraser Government in any period.

The Government is to be congratulated on the way it has maintained the level of funding at about $1,250m over the last four years, given the tremendous constraints and pressures that existed to cut funds even further. It would have been very easy for the Government to say, `The road construction area does not affect us. It is the States and local governments that spend it. We do not have to live with the end result. It is easy for us to reduce the funds and save expenditure. It is an easy way of getting $100m or $200m more'. Even though there have been reductions in spending in real terms, I congratulate the Government on maintaining road construction funds at a very high level. As soon as economic circumstances allow, road funding allocations will again begin to rise as, quite clearly, there is a need for it. Given the financial constraints, the Government should be congratulated on the maintenance of the program and of funds at their current level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ordinary Australians spend one dollar in every seven of their expenditure, about 15 per cent, on freight. Freight is carried in many ways around Australia, by sea and by rail. A significant amount has always been carted by road. The competitive factor of the road component has kept the system honest. I wonder how many dollars each Australian may have had to contribute above that one in seven, that 15 per cent, if it had not been for the competition provided by the road transport sector and, in that arena, by the owner-driver, who has been the real engine of competition in the area. He is a great contributor to road costs. The ordinary and typical owner-driver contributes 30 per cent of his revenues in one form of taxation or another.

SPEECH.PARA: On a 1,000-mile journey some years ago I calculated that the sales tax on the tyres of a rig I operated represented a cost to me of 50c per tonne for that journey. So owner-drivers make a substantial contribution. Any student of the Budget would be well aware that the total of that contribution has never been spent on roads. Not even a fraction of the tax that is taken from road transport fuel is used on roads. Nevertheless, that is the sort of contribution owner-drivers make.

Australians are great users of roads with the vehicles they own. Australians have always used and always will use cars. That is their preference. If we had a better road system, instead of State governments continuing to pour thousands of millions of dollars each year into their public transport systems, we might find ourselves financially better off. The States are losing $3,000m a year overall on public transport. I have heard it argued that if they were to set fire to the lot, on a reasonable wear-out basis they could buy all their regular customers a motor car apiece with the money they would save. That is something to be considered.

Today we are talking about the priority of road construction in our normal Budget approach. Speaker after speaker, even those from the Government benches, has had to admit that the Government is not increasing its commitment to road construction, irrespective of the fact that travel by road is the preferred method of travel for Australians. What is more, it makes a huge contribution towards keeping the cost of our ordinary freight at a reasonable level.

People in my electorate, in particular, are very concerned about the cost of freight, not only of the goods that are bought and consumed to keep home and life together in the rural areas, but also in getting the produce of the region out. The Government, to its credit, is conducting a royal commission into grain storage, handling and transport. Its discussion paper No. 1 tells us that the cost of freight and handling, as a percentage of the total value of a tonne of wheat, is now 52.7 per cent. That goes to many bodies, such as overseas shipping companies, handling companies, et cetera. Of the value of a tonne of wheat 10.4 per cent goes in rail freight. At times, some of that wheat is carted by road. The Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport, in its preliminary findings, said that to get more efficiency into the system, to lower the cost to farmers and to get that 52 per cent down to a much more reasonable level, would require more accent on road transport compared with rail transport. That is true. In Western Australia 1,200 tonnes of wheat is shifted per kilometre of rail track. The iron ore districts are shifting 80,000 tonnes of iron ore per kilometre of rail track. It is easy to see that in many parts of Australia we cannot afford both systems.

There has been a wonderful use of figures today. Everybody has chosen the figures that have suited him. But there is only one real set of comparative figures, and that is, how many kilometres or metres of road can be built for a dollar. I am advised that in the last five years the cost of building one kilometre of road anywhere has increased to about 50 per cent more than when this Government came to office. I am not necessarily blaming this Government, although quite a bit of blame must rest there. I am saying that the increase of 50 per cent in the cost represents about 30 or 40 per cent less road. We should take that into account when we start patting ourselves on the back and complimenting ourselves on the way in which we spend money.

I was interested to hear that the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) started his argument with the base year of 1981-82. Apparently he assumes that because this Government administered the 1982-83 Budget for three months, somehow it was its Budget. I do not remember it having much input into the estimates. These are the silly sorts of things the Government does. When the Australian land transport program was introduced by the then Minister, he was at pains to make comparisons as to how much his Government had increased road expenditure. He also wanted to go back a whole year to avoid one particular factor; that is, in the last Fraser Budget, the Fraser Government commenced the Australian bicentennial road development (ABRD) program. This is the only contributor to additional expenditure on roads that has occurred since. The Minister wanted to dodge that to try to make a sensible comparison.

The honourable member for Capricornia did not even bother to do what some of his colleagues wanted to do, which was to speak in real terms. He wanted to speak in nominal terms and to make comparisons between the amounts of money that were expended in 1981-82 or in 1982-83 and the money being spent today. The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) told us that in the comparable five-year period his Government spent more in real terms than the Fraser Government spent. That is true, if we do not take into account the fact that the Fraser Government introduced the bicentennial road development program, which is what has made the difference. It was an initiative of a previous government. Anybody who suggests that the generosity of this Governmnent is diverting that money to the Australian people, so that they can have better roads, must realise that that is a load of rubbish. It is money contributed by the Australian people, by the process of a 2c per litre levy on fuel. Thank goodness it is directed to a trust fund where the Treasurer (Mr Keating) cannot get his hands on it. Honourable members can bet their bottom dollar that, if he could, he would have been sneaking bits out of that too, and the money would not have been spent on the very necessary requirement of road construction. The 1987-88 estimate for roads is $764m from ordinary Budget sources. The ABRD program is contributing $480m straight out of the motorist's pocket. He contributes hugely to government revenues, and I will refer to that later. When the ABRD program started in 1982-83 the Fraser Government spent $750m in nominal terms on roads.

Is it not amazing that the honourable member for Capricornia continually wants to get back to the discussion about pinching other government's Budgets? This Government is very flexible about other governments' Budgets. Apparently it wanted to steal the credit for the 1982-83 Budget from Mr Fraser. With the problems Mr Fraser had with that Budget, perhaps he would have been pleased to have given it to this Government. But suddenly we have the Treasurer blaming us for the 1983-84 Budget, which this Government wrote in its entirety. It had an $8,000m deficit, and it would like to blame that on somebody else. I tell Government members who spoke previously that they cannot have their cake and eat it. It is nice to take the best of one Budget and to give the worst of its own away. But in real terms, the nominal $750m expenditure in 1982-83 is $994m if expressed in 1986-87 dollars. As I said, that was just at the start of the ABRD scheme.

I have already mentioned that in terms of metres of road constructed the situation changes even more dramatically. Let us say, for the sake of comparison, that in 1982-83 $750m would have paid for the construction of 750 million metres of road. It would not have done so really and the cost would have varied from place to place. But, based on a 50 per cent increase in road construction costs, $750m would today pay for only 500 million metres of road. In other words, in metres of road, we are getting 30 per cent less for the same expenditure today. For the last four years this Government has held its expenditure at approximately $1,250m per annum, including the 2c levy under the bicentennial road development program, which is contributed directly by motorists, truck drivers and others. If we again estimate that four years ago we got 1,250 million metres of road, this year we will get 900 million metres of road. That is the sort of comparison that we should be making. I thought it was amazing that the honourable member for Dobell wanted to make that comparison in real terms when, if he had looked at page 205 of Budget Paper No. 1, he would have seen the bar graph in nominal terms and seen that there has been no increase in expenditure whatsoever over the last four years.

The Government's real contribution, outside of the 2c ABRD levy, has been decreasing in nominal terms. It has decreased from almost $800m. In fact, I think the Minister, in his second reading speech on the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Bill 1985, referred to the figure of $810m. It is a little hard to see it in this graph, but the contribution to the Australian land transport road program, which the Minister made such a fuss about when he introduced it in 1985 for the 1985-86 financial year, has been reduced in nominal terms. This Government has maintained the $1,250m level by its very fortunate increase-to be expected, because it is so many cents per litre-in the ABRD levy, a direct contribution by Australian motorists.

So we can see for ourselves that there is no great commitment by this Government to roads. To use some of this Government's terminology, it was the previous Liberal Government which took the hard decision and imposed an additional 2c per litre tax. But at least we had the decency to include in that legislation the provision that the money would go into a trust fund and would be spent on roads. We have seen a massive growth in the taxes on fuel under this Government-from about 6c a litre to close to 20c a litre. But no amount of that additional money has been spend on roads, although it has all been taken from the motorists. We have heard all the arguments-the argument of convenience, the argument of cost and the argument of safety. They have all been ignored by this Government. Comparisons of the type that have been made here today are scandalous.

Someone talked of priorities. Let us look at other areas of government expenditure. Because of the extravagance of this Government's first two or three Budgets, which resulted in a total of $24,000m worth of increased borrowings, of deficit, we have seen the interest bill jump from $3,300m in the Fraser years to $7,850.9m this year, or $7,851m if you like. That amount is about the same as last year, so I cannot say that that is an increase. But this year the Government is spending $1,032m on culture and recreation, which is an increase over that for last year of 8.8 per cent. It is spending $1,392m on foreign affairs and overseas aid-money being given to people in other parts of the world who may not even thank us for it-which is an increase of 6.9 per cent. On the other hand, the area of transport and communications, which is substantially what we are discussing today, has a vote of $1,661m, which is down 0.5 per cent in nominal terms although, as we know, in nominal terms the road revenue stays the same.

Let us look at the other side, at the Government's revenue. Revenue this year from the taxes on fuel levied by this Government will be $7,000m. One of this Government's early policy decisions was to index the excise on fuel. Of course, by doing that, it created its own brand of inflation; it got a self-generating tax. The price of fuel is included in the consumer price index and the CPI is used to index the excise. So by increasing the excise, that increases the price of fuel, which increases the CPI, which means a built-in increase for six months later. Has that not been working? The revenue from last year has increased by $300m or 4 per cent. It is a pity that that could not have been spent on roads.

I want to make a final point on all of this. I have made a personal, if casual, representation to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) on this point. The ABRD money is aimed primarily at new road construction. It is sorted out and even parcelled out to local government, State governments and others. That has been the policy, and a lot of roads have been built. A lot of roads have been built with other funding. A lot of those roads, particularly some in my electorate, now need substantial maintenance. The maintenance they need most is to be resealed. Many of them have just reached that critical point where, if they are sprayed with hot bitumen and recoated with aggregate, they will probably last twice their original life. I have seen that happen time and again from my local government and earth moving experience. Once we let a bitumen seal start to crack, the water gets through the seal into the road base, the road base turns back to putty, it squeezes out and potholes develop. Once there are a few potholes, even with a full time gang patching them up, they will not hold in the ground and it gets to the position where the whole road has to be torn up and we have to start again from scratch. It is a tragedy when that is allowed to happen.

Many of the local authorities in my electorate, and no doubt all around Australia, need to reseal roads. They have built roads with the money that they have received earlier. They still have numbers of roads to build, to seal, to make more safe and more economic for people. But it is beyond their normal resources now, even with other grants, to carry out a proper resealing program on all the roads that need it. I ask the Minister to consider-it would be to his credit if he did so-making a simple decision that ABRD funds can be used for that resealing program if a particular local authority decides that is the way it would like to spend its money. That is good housekeeping. It should be done, and it is much better that we save the roads that we have rather than go through a program of continually building new roads and having to tear others up. The latter is not good housekeeping and it is not something to which we should contribute.

The Minister may say that in that $750m there are sufficient funds for that purpose. But the funds do not always arrive in the local authorities in particular in a way in which they can be spent on resealing. Some local authorities at this stage would probably vote their entire road funding money to resealing, to maintain their roads, if they could. Of course, sometimes roads need to be widened and it is easier for that to be done in the process of resealing. Many roads built years ago were built very narrow. We have discovered in Western Australia that the way to give a road a long life and to make it safe is to make a 25 feet wide seal. One can then put a white line on the edge. The reality is that we do not beat the edges out and the road lasts a lot longer.

It is useless for the Government to say that 30 per cent less expenditure on roads than four years ago is a satisfactory target. It is absolutely not. That is the reality of the Government's maintaining the expenditure on roads during that period at $1,250m. The funding made available by the Fraser Government from general revenue built more kilometres of road than is the case today. Of course, the ABRD initiative must be credited to the Fraser Government. It put the tax on and it took the odium of that. It was the Fraser Government that started the scheme and it is ridiculous for this Government to make any claims about it. I suggest that, if the money were not in a trust fund, the Government would have paid it out to one of the other areas that I mentioned earlier and left people with half the number of roads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill. Having listened to the debate, one would think from the words of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) that this Government was landed with some excellent roads. But the roads were in a state of absolute disrepair when this Government came to office in 1983. Children were unable to get to school and people were unable to get to hospital, partly because of the long drought which existed just before we came into government but also partly because the Government of the day declined to recognise the rapid deterioration of roads, which were being kept in some semblance of order only because there had not been a lot of rain, particularly in New South Wales. I recall when we came into government that children were unable to get to school and people unable to get to hospital because of the bad state of the roads.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor said that the Fraser Government used its petrol tax properly. It was the Fraser Government which locked petrol taxes, petrol prices, into the general system of taxation revenue. It certainly did not use all those petrol taxes-this is a new idea which has come from the honourable member for O'Connor-purely for road works. It is a great concept. But it was his Government which locked petrol taxes into the general taxation system.

The honourable member for O'Connor and the honourable member for Cowper spoke of no increases in road funding in recent years. I point out to the honourable member for O'Connor that he ignored the fact that in Western Australia total funding for urban, rural, arterial and local roads increased by $11m between the 1986-87 and 1987-88 financial years. I point out to the honourable member for Cowper that total funding for urban arterial, rural arterial and local roads in New South Wales-his State and mine-increased by approximately $23m. As far as rural arterial and local roads are concerned-after all, we are both rural members-funding was up by $22.6m. So the Opposition cannot talk about there being no increases. There have been substantial increases. I believe that the New South Wales Government will make proper use of those funds, as will local councils. Points that have been made on both sides of the House about the importance of road funding certainly bear recognition in this House. I particularly refer to the point made by the honourable member for O'Connor about freight costs being lower when roads are good. We can look at a road close to this Territory, the coast road or trunk road 51, which joins Canberra-Queanbeyan to the South Coast and the Prince's Highway at Bateman's Bay. That road has a long history of problems. It was originally bitumenised by the Menzies Government, but it included an escape mechanism stating that the road thereafter was the responsibility of State governments. There was to be no special recognition by the Federal Government of any obligation to that road. If one looks at the condition of the road today, while recognising some areas of great improvement, particularly the Doughboy Hill area under the community employment program, one would have to recognise that there is an urgent need for upgrading, particularly between Queanbeyan and Bungendore. When one considers the amount of material that is delivered to the Australian Capital Territory via that road, one realises that there is a strong argument for maintaining it in good repair to minimise freight costs-the costs of the contractors, the owner-drivers and others involved in freighting goods to and from the coast, to and from some of the sand mining areas in the Yarrowlumla Shire. There is an urgent need for higher priority to be given by the New South Wales Government to trunk road 51.

Another factor which needs to be mentioned is that funding for arterial roads can save costs on the upgrading of other routes. Great savings could be made by improving trunk road 92, the link between the Goulburn-Queanbeyan-Braidwood areas to the northern part of the South Coast-in other words, the Wollongong, Port Kembla, Milton and Ulladulla areas. It could be improved by putting a reasonable gravel surface on it and later by sealing it. That link would be important for tourists who may want to visit, for instance, the snow fields. It would be an alternative route for people from Sydney, enabling them to go through Nowra, Braidwood and Cooma to the Snowy Mountains. It would also be an important link for the delivery of goods from Canberra to Jervis Bay and from Goulburn to Port Kembla. It would be worth upgrading the Kangaroo Valley link, trunk road 51, to take vast increases in freight delivery and tourist traffic.

Tourism can make money for local communities. I refer to the Pambula-Mount Darragh-Bombala link. It would be a great link for tourists interested in travelling an alternative route to the Prince's Highway from Melbourne, to Cann River, to Bombala and then down to the coast. This would open up some beautiful forests and areas which could be used for family excursions and picnics. It could become a tourist attraction. That link is in urgent need of upgrading, particularly between Wyndham and Pambula, and in some areas between Wyndham and Bombala. If the road were upgraded to the extent that has been requested by local people, it would not only assist employment in the area by making it worth while for people to travel some distance to their jobs, but also would assist tourism in the area. People have told me that their vehicles have broken down and they have become unemployed because they were unable to go to work at Merimbula or at Bombala because of the condition of that road.

Good roads save vehicle costs. Many people travel between Eden and Towamba. I went on a school bus trip between Eden and Towamba one evening and I recall that on that trip the windscreen wipers dropped off the bus. A bit further on the accelerator pedal dropped off. The bus is in a bad state of repair, certainly; it has to be kept in repair. The proprietor is unwilling to buy a new vehicle because of the dreadful state of the road.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you go for another ride on that bus?

—I may go for another ride on the bus, but I would perhaps have a look at it before I left as one would, on occasions, check an aeroplane before flying. The Eden-Towamba road is in urgent need of repair. I compliment the Bega Valley Shire on the work it has done to upgrade its roads. I urge the New South Wales Government to use that extra $22.6m which has been made available to it for rural arterial and local roads. Another road of importance is the Millingandi by-pass which links Pambula to the Prince's Highway by-passing Merimbula. That road has excellent bitumen for some of its length but it deteriorates. I travelled on it yesterday. It will not be very long before there is an accident on that road if it is not upgraded.

SPEECH.PARA: I compliment the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) and the previous Minister for Transport on their application of the recommendations of the Cameron inquiry into road funding which was set up in 1985. That inquiry established three principles: first, it called for effort neutrality which really meant that local or State governments were not to be penalised for effort. Secondly, it called for a principle of construction and maintenance. Thirdly, it called for a principle of periodic review of data sources supporting the committee's indicators and their weighting in accordance with Federal objectives. The indicators of road funding and requirements relate first to axle loading. This reflects the effort involved in building and maintaining pavements to withstand vehicle traffic. The indicators relate secondly to road occupancy which reflects the effort that is needed to build a necessary number of lanes to accommodate traffic.
