SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join in the debate on the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987. I wish to talk broadly on the legislation and to point out to the House some aspects of concern to me in relation to the funding for road construction and maintenance throughout Australia. We have to appreciate the fact that whilst the Commonwealth supplies a certain amount of funding to all the States for roads, apart from the national roads aspect, basically it is the responsibility of the States to decide with the local councils where they will direct the funding that they receive.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three ways in which the Commonwealth provides assistance for roads. There is the legislation before the House, which entails a direct contribution from the petrol tax fund. There is also the Australian bicentennial road development program, whereby a levy of 2c per litre is imposed on all the fuel purchased in Australia. Thirdly, there is the personal taxation fund, which comes by way of an untied grant from the Commonwealth to all the local government bodies. These three sources of finance for road funding in Australia-and to other local government works-are most important to councils. We have a tendency today to place a greater responsibility on local government generally to meet the demands of the community, which are very broad and very great. Having served on a council myself, I always say that roads are the No. 1 local government responsibility. The services of sewerage, water supply, parklands, kerbing and guttering, pavements and the like are very important also, but today we find that councils are faced with a broader responsibility within their areas, particularly insofar as welfare is concerned.

Of those three methods of road funding that I mentioned earlier, the two most important are the legislation now before the House, the land transport fund legislation, and the bicentennial road funding program. This is because the money that is allocated for those two funds must go directly to Australian roads, whereas the other method of funding, the personal taxation fund, provides, as I said earlier, untied grants which the councils may spend as they see fit, even to offset increases in rate levels within their particular areas.

Australia has a great responsibility for roads. I know that the Government can argue that there is today a need for restraint. We in the Opposition agree with that. We all advocate restraint. But it is a matter of priorities: it is a question of what one lot wants and what the other lot wants. So, as a representative of a country electorate, I want to say that I hold roads as one of the great responsibilities that we have-along with defence, of course. Australia depends so much upon roads because they are the means of carting our produce to markets. They further the tourist industry within Australia. They are important in transporting children to school. There are so many aspects of life today, not only in the country but also in the cities, that are dependent upon the communication field.

It is for these reasons that over the years we have seen great advances made in road construction and maintenance. But in dealing with this matter we have to look at four levels of roads. The Commonwealth is directly responsible for national roads throughout the Commonwealth. The arterial road systems are also terribly important to areas of the Commonwealth. There are also our rural and urban local road systems for which the councils are basically responsible. So we have those four different systems of roads throughout Australia. I will not speak about the national roads. I believe that they are very important. I believe that the Government has done its very best to address the problems of national roads. Indeed, I believe it is now the case that we have a bitumen surfaced highway system right around Australia. This is a wonderful achievement for Australia. It is essential.

So now in our plans we are looking to see how we can interlock these additional roads. I think of a railroad from the west to the east and of the rich resources that we have in the north of Australia and in the western parts of New South Wales, and I wonder how over a period we can address ourselves to providing the transport, either rail or road, that is so important in bringing these resources to market.

Today I tuned in to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to hear about our stock market situation. Somebody remarked that in the 1929 depression the primary industries and the resource industries brought this country's economy back to earth again. We believe that this would still apply today. If there is a depression-I trust that there will not be, and we must not talk about it; but there is a recession and we are having problems selling our products on world markets-we will find that it is the agricultural resources of Australia that will bring us back on to a sound footing. It is so important to appreciate the necessity of good roads in order that we provide the facilities that are so necessary to get our farming products into market in our local towns and cities and also to export points, which is essential. The same thing applies to the resource industries of Australia, including the mining industry. It, too, is very dependent upon the roads.

I know that the Opposition has criticised the fact that unfortunately the Commonwealth, over the last four years, has allocated only $1,245m for this category of road finance. This is insufficient. With an inflationary trend of 9 per cent a year, one could say that that amounts to a loss in real money terms of 40 per cent in what the Commonwealth has provided to the States for road expenditure. This has had a serious effect upon these roads I have just been speaking about. In my own electorate of Lyne, from the Port Stephens shire up to the greater city of Taree, we find that a number of our local rural roads and our arterial roads are in need of direct assistance from somewhere.

The average person does not know where the money comes from. People know that they pay tax. They are told occasionally that for every litre of fuel that they buy, about 30c-over 50 per cent of the cost-goes to the Commonwealth and the States. The companies that actually provide the fuel receive only between 10c and 12c a litre. So all of the rest is taken up in costs. The majority of this amount goes to governments, particularly the Commonwealth Government and the New South Wales Government. The New South Wales Government takes a tax of around 7c per litre for every litre of fuel sold in New South Wales. As a matter of interest, our petrol tax is now a very important part of the revenue of the Commonwealth. At the moment it is up to $6,987m, whereas last year it was $6,728m. That is a lot of money-approximately one-tenth of total Commonwealth revenue. So the early days of the 1944 petrol tax Act, which was introduced to provide something like a penny to go towards roads, have gone. We have departed from that, and the present system has come to provide an integral part of taxation revenue for both Commonwealth and State governments.

So it is not unreasonable that we turn around and say, `Right, we know how important country roads are and so we want greater assistance than we get at present'. The efficiency of industry depends greatly on getting the product to market or taking it to where the manufacturing process will be carried out. We need conveyance along the line. A dairyman must have the tanker call to get his milk, and the vegetable grower must have a truck collect his goods and take them off to market, to the city. No matter what is produced on the farm, transport is important. This is also the case with decentralised industry. Manufacturers who set up their industries throughout the Commonwealth of Australia are dependent upon road transport. I know of a number of industries that have decentralised to my electorate and elsewhere that are unable to use rail services because they are not efficient enough when handling manufactured goods. The product has to be looked after, or handled, four times, whereas, if goods can be put on a truck and sent away to market, they need to be handled only twice. That means a lesser cost to industry, and this is why people today want to use road rather than rail services. I do not criticise Australia's rail system; we all know that we can be more efficient in certain things but the fact is that road transport is the most efficient way of moving goods.

Many people, in the city and the country, drive their cars to work. There may not be public transport, or someone may just wish to drive his own vehicle to work. Often when I come to Canberra I travel across the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Nine out of 10 cars contain only one person. A National Roads and Motorists Association survey shows that it is the wish of the people who drive these cars, perhaps because of the work they do, to have the freedom to drive their own cars to work. Nobody can take that right away from them-although the bridge toll has gone up to a dollar, and if the tunnel goes in it will be more. That is what the situation is, and we have to realise that.

This country is very dependent on our road system generally for its future, for its development as a nation, from providing facilities for the transport of goods to enabling us to get our children to school. The other day there was nearly an accident on one of the arterial roads in my electorate, between Stroud and Dungog. Neither of the councils concerned with that road-they are relatively small local government bodies-have the money to spend on it themselves. They are dependent upon money provided under measures such as that before us tonight. Money goes into the coffers of the States, and on to them. I am sure that in New South Wales, where I have some knowledge of the situation, the average council could spend in one year on essential road and bridge works at least 10 years normal allocation from Commonwealth funding programs. I want to emphasise the efficiency of road transport, its actual necessity and how important it is that we build up our road system throughout Australia. We have to maintain existing roads and certainly build new ones to open up the districts that at present do not have the roads that we believe they should have.

I spoke earlier of the tourist industry. Tourism in Australia is flourishing. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) said at Question Time today that the Japanese tourist intake, particularly in northern Australia, has more than doubled. I was in Cairns the other day, and there is a jumbo jet coming in there every day laden with people from Japan and the United States of America. So we can see the growth. We must accept this industry; we must build upon it, and our communications systems will be vitally important to it.

I mentioned earlier the contribution of government generally to roads, but we ought to keep in mind that in 1982-83 expenditure on roads came to 2.12 per cent of the Commonwealth's total expenditure. Even though the amount may have increased a little because of the bicentennial road development program, it has now come back to 1.6 per cent of Commonwealth expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is about 33 1/3 per cent.

—That is right. As the honourable member for Groom says, there is an actual reduction of about 33 1/3 per cent in the Commonwealth contribution to road funding. We cannot afford to have such a reduction in Australia. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) spoke earlier about the Pacific Highway. We would love to see it upgraded. I commend the former Minister for Transport, the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris), because he did his best to get that road improved as far as Newcastle. It will bypass Newcastle within a year or so, which is wonderful news for us in the north of the State. But a bottleneck will be created on the Pacific Highway north of Newcastle because it will not be able to cope with the demands placed upon it by the heavy transport vehicles and the ordinary motor vehicles which will use it. I think that now, because the State has altered the laws relating to the picking up and putting down of passengers, 28 buses travel from Taree to the metropolitan area each day. So we have this tremendous generation of traffic. We want that to take place but, unfortunately, we will have to demand that the Government upgrade the Pacific Highway. I suppose honourable members on both sides of the House, especially the rural fellows, would say that they have roads in their electorates that are just as deserving. Those roads are the lifeblood of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Occasionally we are inclined to overlook the safety aspect of roads, but that is terribly important. We get so wrapped up in getting a road improved and our goods to market to meet demands that safety is forgotten. I know that much of the problem could be solved if New South Wales had the funds and the inclination to put more police on the roads. On busy weekends, such as the Australia Day weekend, when there are a large number of police on their motorcycles and in their cars patrolling the highways and arterial roads, we find that there is very seldom an accident, because people are careful. We do not have the manpower available to maintain such a police presence, and that is a shame. It is for that reason that we have to look at improving the safety of our roads for the people who use them.

Australia has a huge circumference and our population is particularly spread out, and I guess it can be argued quite soundly that we are lucky that we have developed our general communications systems in the way that we have over a period of time. I emphasise in conclusion, as my time is nearly up, that the Government of Australia has a great responsibility to allocate priorities to meet the tremendous demand to improve our road system generally throughout the Commonwealth.

That is made up of $770m for the Australian land transport program and $480m for the Australian bicentennial road development program. So there is a dramatic fall in real terms in road funding from last year's allocation, which in itself represented a fall from previous years. Yet we have had an inflation rate of approaching 9 per cent. That is just the consumer price index, but within the construction industry the inflation rate is so much higher because of the fuel component, the heavy machinery component. Not only has the financial allocation for road funding this year in real terms fallen significantly behind last year and the preceding years; it has fallen further behind taking into account the rate of inflation for the road construction industries.

We all know the economic cost of a bad road system in this country-the wear and tear on private motorists' vehicles and trucks and how it affects in a number of ways a line of people associated with the transport industry. But something we do not concentrate on often enough is the safety aspect. I have been taken to parts of Gippsland by police who have identified areas where fatal accidents have occurred only because of the state of the roads. One can talk about improvements on the Princes Highway, as the honourable member for McMillan valiantly tries to do concerning the distance between Dandenong and Traralgon, and make disparaging remarks such as he has made about the supposedly insignificant local roads, but it is the condition of the local roads as much as the condition of the highways that contributes to death and injury. It is not simply an economic argument. Time will not allow me to detail the cost to the community, in terms of injury, health costs and hospitalisation, of bad roads.

The absurdity of all this is that every motorist is paying at least 19c a litre in fuel excise, yet less than 5c a litre of that sum finds its way into the road network. There has to be hypothecation, meaning that whatever is raised by fuel excise goes directly to the road system. The most difficult and bitter pill for motorists to swallow is that only a fraction of fuel excise costs, such a significant part of the cost of petrol, goes to improving the roads they use every day. The Gippsland Municipalities Association which, incidentally, passed a motion of condemnation of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) for failing to attend the last few meetings--

TALK.START.PARA: —They would.

—The honourable member has just accused the Gippsland Municipalities Association of some sort of political colouring or political bias. The honourable member and his ALP colleagues will never turn up at Association meetings. It is extraordinary. The ALP members turn their backs on the democratically elected members of the local government they seek to serve. No wonder the honourable member for McMillan is always in a brawl with one local council or another. It is the best show in Gippsland since Ben Hur. It is the longest running serial since Blue Hills. The honourable member for McMillan is sealing his own political fate with his inability to resist a cheap impersonation of the Treasurer, like so many of his colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress the importance of local roads within our community. There is no doubt that they, more than any other part of the road infrastructure, have suffered from a lack of funding by this Government over several years now. A dual carriageway east of Traralgon and heading towards Sale and beyond to Bairnsdale is quite crucial. Planning for it must start immediately. There is bumper to bumper traffic on the road at peak times. Even outside peak tourist times there is a very heavy vehicle load. This part of Gippsland has boomed. We call it the Riviera of Victoria-Bairnsdale, Paynesville, Orbost, Marlo and Mallacoota. Together with the mountainous region of Heyfield and Licola, it has become the most popular and the most visited part of Victoria. The dual carriageway that runs almost the entire way from Melbourne to Traralgon needs to be extended eastwards so that the dramatic growth in tourism and recreation sports that has occurred in East Gippsland can continue.

In summary, every National Party member could speak at great length about the suffering within their country electorates caused by the drop in road funding. It is a matter of priorities. A government has to make hard decisions and decide what is more important than any other issue. To my way of thinking, unless this Government takes the issue of road funding far more seriously than it has ever demonstrated before, this country, which is so dependent on rural industries, will have little future to look forward to. I urge the Government to rethink its strategy and allocation for road funding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

I point out to the honourable member for Gippsland that the latest figures on what has been made available to Victoria show that for rural arterial roads there has been a reduction of $2.4m, for urban arterial roads an increase of $2.8m and for local roads a reduction of only $700,000. The honourable member for Gippsland raised the matter of my allegedly speaking to the Warragul Shire on road funding. He has been on local television on this matter. It is a bit of a running sore. It received a reply from the General Manager, Norm Butler, saying that no Federal government funds were available for the road at that time.

It is an area of which any person, any honourable member, would be very proud. I am not saying anything about the people who live there. They are all decent people. They have a bitumen road which goes from their little township of Buln Buln into Warragul. It is fully sealed-a beautiful road. A local councillor, who just happens to have been elected to the council recently and who happens to be the only farmer who lives on the sealed section of Christies Road, would like to have all the road sealed by taxpayers. When he pushed it at council, council asked for a report from the police. We had a report from a policeman who happened to live in Buln Buln and who also used the road. He said how serious it was. I am sure that the honourable member for Gippsland would be very interested in one area I wish to raise. We have had a golden egg in Australia since 1975 or 1976, about the time when the coup took place, when Fraser stepped in and decided that he could manage this country better than the Labor Government could. At that time Bass Strait oil came on stream, and we had the greatest golden egg of revenue to a Federal government of all time. We had the cheapest oil coming out of the ground, we had a boom in world prices, so the difference between the price of the oil coming out of the Bass Strait oil wells and the world price was lucrative cream for the Federal Government. The Fraser Government has on average $3,500m a year to do something with, either to abolish the deficit or to improve road funding; but it did neither. It did nothing for roads and it did nothing for the Budget deficit. It wasted seven years while the Bass Strait oil wells were laying the golden eggs. Now, in 1987, the crunch is coming. Any honourable member who stands up in this House and says that it is a priority to spend funds on a second access for certain people to travel into a country town might sound good in his own electorate but I am sure that the people of McMillan would not concede that he was doing a good job. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to assure the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) that if the day of the golden source to which he referred is over, the day of more and bigger taxes, under this Government, is not over. We are debating a Budget proposal and we are looking ahead to a year in which the Government anticipates, in effect, a bonanza in revenue from additional taxation. In this context we have the contrast-not unusual for this Government-between the rhetoric on the one hand and the performance on the other. We have the rhetoric set out in the second reading speech by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) in which he refers to the provisions in the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments in no way change the Government's commitment to the development of a road network which will meet Australia's national economic objectives.
That is really good stuff. He also said:

The Government's economic agenda clearly focuses on establishing the basis for Australia's long term economic security. An efficient national transport and communications infrastructure is needed to assist in achieving this objective.

But what do we find, as against that commitment? We find that under the programs in this legislation the quantum of money allocated remains as it was last year, and indeed as it was the year before, making no allowance for the impact of inflation in this area so that the program funding has significantly decreased in real terms. That has to be seen in a context of the totality of this Budget. It is not as though the Government is seriously restricting its spending, the need for which was recognised, of course, by Senator Walsh in the other place. The Government thereby squandered an opportunity to make a significant impact on this country's vast balance of payments deficit problem and crippling overseas debt problem. We have had the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tell us that there has been a 2.4 per cent real cut in Commonwealth spending-`the biggest cut in the 35 years for which comparable records are available'-a cut in outlays of upwards of $3,000m.

The truth, if we look at this closely, is that, yes, there is a cut of $1,000m, about one-third of that total, in grants to the States. Then we look at the next big item of $1,000m coming from-would you believe it-asset sales. The sale of land in Tokyo and our Embassy in Paris and some like items to the order of $1,000m is entered as a cut in expenditure, nearly one-third of the total. It is all here in the Budget Papers if honourable members want to study it. Nearly one-third of this much vaunted cut-the biggest cut in 35 years-is $1,000m of asset sales!

If we look at the remainder, the situation is that Commonwealth spending for its own purposes has in fact gone up slightly in real terms, and more in money terms. That is the true position in relation to this much vaunted cut in expenditure. Yet in this vital area of roads, to which the Minister attested such priority in his speech, the allocation remains constant in money terms-indeed, slightly reduced by virtue of allocating some to administrative charges-and is significantly down in real terms. I emphasise this point in the debate because one sees the impact of this at the city level, as well as at the country level as my colleagues the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and others have emphasised.

I want to refer in particular to the freeway under construction between Pearce's Corner and Berowra in my electorate. This is a most important road. In fact I was very active in achieving the original approval for this as a `national highway' from the predecessor of my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland, the Hon. Peter Nixon. I used to be referred to by the then shire President as `Expressway Edwards' for having got that approval through.

—That is not a bad suggestion from my colleague; that may be taken on board. The fact is that this stretch of national highway is of vital significance and of the highest priority. All the traffic from the east, the south and much of the west of Sydney must funnel through Hornsby, in the centre of my electorate, on the way north; it is the only way. From a defence point of view, if ever there were a major accident at Hornsby-the way big trucks thunder through there, there could well be-the road north could be seriously blocked. I hope that those statements that I have referred to may be wrong. I would be interested to hear the Minister's view.

Peter Morris, now the Minister for Resources, has done what he can for the project. Perhaps the State Government in New South Wales as an agent for the Commonwealth in this matter, has intervened. We have in the Unsworth State Labor Government in New South Wales a government consumed with the provision of `monuments and circuses' for the people--

—As my colleague the honourable member for Kooyong says, it is, of course, the Unsworth-Brereton Government. Of course, Brereton insists on getting up front. I am not quite sure what Mr Unsworth thinks about that. But, yes, the Unsworth-Brereton Government is precisely the one to which I refer.
—Neville Wran wants to come back.

—We seem to have heard a lot about him in the Press lately. Perhaps the New South Wales Government is sending out a distress call-not that it would do much good; but there it is. It is possible that in this way there has been a diversion of funds from this very vital highway. But I draw the attention of the House to the way in which this Pearces Corner-Berowra expressway is an absolutely vital commercial and, indeed, defence artery in the north of the city of Sydney, the progress of which has visibly slowed and is, I believe, a reflection of the allocation, or misallocation, of the funds that we are discussing here tonight.

I hope the Government will direct its attention to this very important issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the case which has been put in this debate for more funding for roads-national highways, arterial roads and local roads. There is no doubt that the legislation before the House, the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill, short-changes the road system of Australia. In so doing, it has deplorable consequences in so many respects. I briefly refer to the circumstances relating to the Pacific Highway in the electorate of Page and, in particular, that section of the highway between Grafton and Maclean, recognised throughout New South Wales as the most needy section of the highway for upgrading.

SPEECH.PARA: Grants were authorised by the Federal Minister for Transport, the predecessor of the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), yet this funding has not flowed through in an effective way. We see the most incredible botch in respect of road construction that one could find anywhere in Australia. The blame perhaps lies with the New South Wales Government. There was reference earlier to the New South Wales Minister for Roads and the disabilities that that State is suffering at present. Perhaps it is no exaggeration to say that crucial funding has been diverted from roads such as the Pacific Highway to the Darling Harbour project in Sydney, to expressways related to the development of the Darling Harbour project. If that is the case it is, I believe, a very sad reflection on the administration of the road funds, particularly those funds provided by the Federal Government for essential road works in New South Wales.

The problem to which I refer is one in which there have been allocations made for very urgent realignment of sections of the highway which no longer have adequate carriageway for traffic volumes of immense proportions. That reconstruction work has been going on month by month on a stop-go basis for almost two years. What has become of the funds that have been allocated? What arrangements were made between the Federal department and the State department in respect of this project? It boggles the mind to see the equipment and the engineering that would have been involved and to see that stop-start process that has occurred on the worst section of the Pacific Highway in New South Wales. Yet that project comes to a halt because of insufficient funds. The authorisation announced at least two years ago by the former Federal Minister was, of course, seized upon by the State Minister with a further announcement saying, `Yes, the funding is there. The work will be carried out'. In fact, it is a total mess. The work is totally inadequate. The most accident-prone section of the highway is totally neglected.

In the limited time I have available I do not want to canvass more than two significant points that have been alluded to in this debate. The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) said that an additional $50,000 had been authorised. What can be done with $50,000 on essential road works? Most local authorities, certainly in New South Wales, find that they are unable to construct any new sections of road of a worthwhile magnitude for $50,000. In fact the councils in my electorate have a program, which is part of the New South Wales scheme of things, in which new construction is limited to less than one kilometre a year. In a local government area where, to be effective, there is a need for, say, 15, 20 or 30 kilometres of road to be constructed, the $50,000 that the honourable member for McMillan mentioned would not pay for the construction a fraction of a kilometre of a rural arterial road or a rural local road. The reality is that if we compare the funding for expressways, major bridge construction and so on, to the needs of local government, we see that it has been left behind in a way that is tragic for the future of the road systems in Australia. Shires such as Kyogle in northern New South Wales, one of the larger council areas with an enormous road length, have no increase in road funding. There is no adequate increase in their share of personal tax reimbursement. There is no adequate provision for an ongoing program of road maintenance, let alone adequate road construction. The position is totally unsatisfactory. The contraction in funding makes the position worse and the Government's record is abysmal.

The debate throws up the suggestion that there are other categories from which funding can come to assist local authorities. We know that that is wrong. We know that in practice it does not occur. We need to face up to the fact that there will continue to be tragic road accidents, tragic loss of life, tragic depletion of road standards unless this situation is reversed. I strongly support those who in this debate have brought this point so forcefully to the House tonight.

This road, that road, that back road, the other front road-every road that honourable members opposite cared to mention in this Parliament tonight-seemed to be in dire straits, collapsing and falling apart. One is led to say to oneself, `Surely this absolute mayhem of road disasters could not have happened just in the last three or four years'. Of course it could not have. That just shows how little credibility honourable members opposite have. What has happened in this nation in the last four years-and that is all the time that this Government has had to set right the mess that we were left with as a result of the legacy of the Fraser Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —You call a $30 billion to $100 billion foreign debt setting things right? Have you got our foreign debt right?

—We have had only four years to correct the situation, and that is exactly what we have done. I can only put the jaundiced view of the honourable member for Deakin and others on the other side of the chamber down to what has gone on in the stock market today. I think that they must have come in here with something on their liver as a result of that and they are not able to see things in a fair and proper way. I can only put it down to something of that sort, because the record of this Government in the roads area is a tremendous one of which we can be very proud.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a few matters that ought to be dealt with. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), for example, in a quite extraordinary performance, had the cheek to talk about road safety as if he had invented or discovered it. I just point out to him that, when the Fraser Government was swept from the treasury bench, the Australian Government under Fraser had spent not one dollar on road safety. This Government in this Budget is spending in excess of $6m. We have recognised the problem of road safety and are doing something about it. That is more than can be said for the tatty, sorry record of the Fraser Government on that matter.

The second thing that the honourable member for Gippsland said was that funds in Victoria were siphoned off from rural areas to be spent in Melbourne-blaming either the Federal Government or the Victorian Government. He was not very specific about that, but he certainly intended to indicate to the people of Australia that somehow or other these Labor governments, the Federal Government and the Victorian Government, with some sort of sleight of hand, were siphoning off into the Melbourne metropolis funds that were meant to be spent in rural areas. I say to him that nothing could be further from the truth. Seventy-five per cent of the funds spent by this Government on road funding are spent in the rural areas of this nation. Let us get that figure on the record: 75 per cent plus of the funds spent by the Hawke national Government are spent on rural Australian roads-on national highways in rural areas, on rural arterial roads or on rural local roads. That is the fact and it ought to be placed on the record.

Another matter that ought to be dealt with was raised by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), which I found particularly interesting. In a strange way he complained that a particular road in his area that ran from Queensland into New South Wales had not had enough money spent on it. He wanted more money spent on it. When pressed a little bit, he admitted that the road on the New South Wales side of the border was in much better nick than the road on the Queensland side. I say to him that, as a member of the National Party of Australia, he had better get on to old Joh and have a chat with him, because the fact of the matter is that the decisions on which roads of the rural variety are done up with Federal funds are made essentially by the State governments. If Joh and the Nationals in Queensland are not spending enough on the back roads of Maranoa, the National Party member for Maranoa had best address his comments to his National Party colleagues in Queensland. To be fair, he ought to give credit where credit is due-to the New South Wales Labor Government for spending the appropriate moneys on its side of the border to have that road in reasonable nick.

Petrol pricing details were raised by the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck). Every year he trots out exactly the same speech. He says, on the one hand, that far too much money is being taken out of the motorists' pocket, pushing up the price of petrol, particularly in Tasmania, of course, and, on the other hand, that we are not spending enough money on roads in Tasmania. I simply say to my friend the honourable member for Franklin that he cannot have it both ways. He knows that perfectly well. But he does not really want the situation changed too much; otherwise he would have to get himself a new speech, and that would be for him a pretty interesting circumstance in which to find himself.

There are a couple of other matters I could raise, but I do not want to take the time of the Parliament. I simply say to the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) that the rumours that he is spreading about work being suspended on the Newcastle freeway are nothing more than furphies. They are not true. The work on that road will continue and we will have a very fine road there which, in my view, ought to be named the Morris Highway. Certainly, the former Minister responsible for the area, now the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris), was a great supporter of that road, and there is no doubt that he did a great deal to assist in the building of it.

I conclude by saying simply that this legislation will continue the funding of the Australian road system essentially in a fashion which will ensure that we can continue the great effort that has been made under the Hawke Government to build a better road system in this nation. We will continue this building of the road system. We will say to the Australian people in the next election campaign, `You be the judge of the efforts we have made. Do you want to go back to the Fraser years when funding was less than 24 per cent in real terms of what it will be this year, or do you want to continue the real effort to build a national road infrastructure of which we as Australians can all be proud?'. I have no doubt that the Australian people will make the judgment that this Government has done a very good job in road building and continues to do a good job. It will therefore be re-elected at the next election so that we can continue the work that we have already begun for the benefit of the nation.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (GENERAL REVENUE) AMENDMENT BILL 1987[COGNATE BILL:STATES (WORKS AND HOUSING) ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 September, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill concurrently with the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill and the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill basically put into effect decisions made at the May 1987 Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting. The Opposition will not oppose the Bills. The States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill represents $13.5 billion of Commonwealth general revenue payments to State governments, while the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill represents payments of $0.5 billion through the State governments' Loan Council program. These figures should be put in perspective. If we add to the payments under these Bills specific purpose payments for such things as health and education, payments to the State and local government sectors represent about 30 per cent of total Commonwealth outlays. That is a very significant slice of total payments.

SPEECH.PARA: This tells us that the legislation we are debating tonight is extremely important. What these Bills do not tell us, in their dry legalisms, is that the Commonwealth Government has been cutting its Budget payments to the States progressively over the term of its office, while at the same time it has not seen fit to match the extent of those cuts with reductions in its own purpose payments. Budget Paper No. 4 tells us that outlays by the Commonwealth for its own purposes, net of proceeds from assets sales, are to increase by 7.1 per cent in 1987-88. That represents growth in real terms. However, Budget payments to the other levels of government in 1987-88 are estimated to record only a 2.4 per cent increase-or in real terms, a significant drop of over 4 per cent.

I am not criticising the Government for reducing payments to the States; with the economy as it is, that is required. The reason I am criticising the Government is the hypocrisy it has shown in demanding spending restraint from all other levels of government while at the same time not matching the bid it asks the States to accept. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) gave pious sermons to the States at the Premiers Conference on the need for expenditure reductions to meet the country's economic difficulties. A week prior to that, when the May economic statement was presented to the Parliament, they sermonised on the same topic saying that we must adjust to meet our external difficulties. Several weeks after that they sermonised again, for the September Budget. But sermonising, as all know, is not action. They are prepared to ask the States to pull back outlays but they are happy to be easier on themselves.

It is just this sort of lax attitude that Senator Peter Walsh, the Government's own Minister for Finance, has been frightened by. As all Australia knows, he has warned that unless there are changes in this Government's economic policy, he can see us facing the Argentinean road. Indeed, beyond seeing it, he says we are heading down it. Alongside that road is a sign that points to Labor's debt, to the $83 billion net foreign debt which this Government has given us. Our foreign debt has quadrupled during the period of the Hawke-Keating Government.

The Opposition's view on this has been stated time and again in recent months-namely, that our pace of adjustment is too slow. The Government had its opportunity in the Budget but it was not prepared to make the necessary quality cuts in its own programs. Nonetheless, the call for States to share the burden of fiscal restraint is in itself appropriate. All governments in Australia-indeed, most Western governments that have been profligate-must realise the need to reduce growth in their recurrent expenditure at a time when real incomes have been falling. The States of our nation do represent a large share of the total outlays.

Budget Paper No. 1 tells us that total public sector outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) were 41.6 per cent in 1986-87. The State and local government sectors represented just over half of that, at 21.2 per cent of outlays. In addition, when we talk about reducing the public sector borrowing requirement-that is, the money governments have needed to borrow from the private sector to fund their excessive recurrent expenditure programs-we find that there is more to the calculation than simply the Commonwealth Budget deficit. Budget Paper No. 1 informs us that in 1986-87 the total public sector borrowing requirement was 3.8 per cent of GDP, or around $10 billion. The Commonwealth accounted for 1.5 per cent of that amount expressed as a proportion of GDP, and the State sector 2.3 per cent-that is, the States accounted for 61 per cent of the total public sector borrowing requirement in 1986-87. Certainly for many years the States have represented the significant share.

So when it is argued that earlier excessive growth in public sector expenditure is one of the main causes of our existing external difficulties, that of course includes State sector expenditure. That we should contain total government spending so as to allow the public sector to make room for the private sector, particularly private investment, is an argument that we can apply equally to State governments. However, recent experience does show that some States are just not prepared to undergo this recently applied restraint. In Sydney, the Unsworth-Brereton Government has budgeted for the highest increase in recurrent expenditure of all governments for 1987-88. In addition, I commented three weeks ago in this House that the net debt of the State of New South Wales grew by some $2 1/2 billion over the last financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much was that?

—It was $2 1/2 billion. Do we smell an election around the corner? Forget responsible economic management; it is pork-barrelling that seems more important to the New South Wales Government than fiscal rectitude. In Adelaide Mr Bannon runs a Treasury that some refer to as the best merchant bank in Australia. It borrows money, hoards it away in hollow logs, and switches it from one type of security to the next, and yet we have to ask where is the long term benefit to South Australians. Government officials are not employed to be bond market cowboys. Governments should stay out of the financial markets as much as possible so as to allow private investors unencumbered access.

SPEECH.PARA: In Perth, the Burke Labor Government took the honours last year for presenting the largest increases in recurrent expenditure. In my own State capital of Melbourne, Mr Cain claims that he does not have the hollow logs that the other States can call upon. Obviously that is because his Government spends every cent it can get its hands on to expand its expenditure on questionable programs, to increase the number of government employees providing those questionable services or to add to those employees' levels of remuneration. The Cain Labor Government presents an extraordinary record.

But what of those hollow logs, the buildup of financial assets that the other States can rely on? These are savings that they can draw on now rather than make the appropriate expenditure reductions that the adjustment tasks require. Those hollow logs were allowed to build up because of the weak hand at the tiller of the Australian Loan Council. After the large legitimate expenditures by States on infrastructure development during the short-lived resources boom, the Hawke-Keating Government capped the States' borrowing ceiling, under the global approach, at too high a level. States were no longer involved in larger infrastructure projects but were still able to borrow large amounts, so they obligingly borrowed the money they were allowed to and of course squirrelled it away. In the process that excessive borrowing, mainly by State Labor governments, contributed as much to squeezing the financial markets and interest rates as the $15 billion deficit of the first two disastrous Keating Budgets.

Therefore, while I indicate that obviously the States have the right to pursue their own policies, one has to add that those rights must be exercised with responsibility. They must bear their fair share of the adjustment process, and ought to be prepared to step up the pace of adjustment, as we demand that the Federal Government step up the pace, to help address our external difficulties.

I conclude by referring to some specific aspects of the Bills before us. The States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill will implement certain Budget proposals that the States will in future be expected to share in meeting some of the costs of higher education superannuation. This suggests to me a transfer of obviously a minor Commonwealth outlay to the States. However, despite its modesty it represents a welcome step in recognising that the centralisation of power in Canberra is, in many cases, the opposite of what is needed.

During the calamitous days of the Whitlam Government the Commonwealth assumed a right, indeed a desire, to intervene in all manner of activities once seen as solely the province of the States. In health, education, road building and innumerable other activities the Commonwealth has established huge bureaucracies. I will give just one example. While the Queensland Department of Health, with its 6,700 or so staff, operates the State's entire public hospital and health system, prior to the recent reorganisation the Commonwealth Department of Health employed some 4,100 public servants not one of whom, according to State governments, provided any direct health service to patients. This is not a bad record of growth in numbers. There is certainly a case for the Commonwealth to review its activities and avoid costly duplication of State functions. It is more appropriate for the States, which employ the teachers, the nurses and the road builders, to be allowed to take the responsibility of conducting their own programs. This does not mean that I am advocating the wholesale removal of Commonwealth funding to the States-I am not on about that-but in many cases block grants would be more efficient than Commonwealth meddling in State affairs.

Finally, I refer to the housing industry as the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill involves nominating arrangements for public housing under the States Loan Council program. The legislation before us indicates that those amounts that can be nominated from the borrowings component under the States Loan Council program will be an estimated $357m in 1987-88. That compares with $534m for this program in 1986-87. That is a very large fall. The bare figures may disguise efficiency gains through program reappraisal and may not, in themselves, represent a neglect by the Government of the poor homeless element in the community. There may be quite legitimate explanations. However, there is no legitimate explanation for why the Government has wreaked havoc in the housing industry in this country. First there was the capital gains tax and the abolition of negative gearing and then the record high interest rate policies of this Government. The rental market for accommodation, especially in Sydney, has been appalling. The Government did a back flip on negative gearing probably more out of sympathy for Barrie Unsworth's poor election chances than for the homeseeker.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will romp home.

—However, that back flip was offset by knee jerk reaction to foreign investment in real estate. If I had not realised that the honourable member who interjected probably dropped a bundle speculating on the market in recent days, I would have challenged him to a wager on the statement he has just made and I would have given him a shade of odds. What a macabre and contorted dance we have seen from this Government in the housing area.
—You would lose your dough too.

—Do not tell me that the honourable member is prepared to put money on the Unsworth-Brereton Government. It is a bit on the nose, mate, I think. I was saying before I was gently interrupted that the Government did a back flip on negative gearing, probably, as I said, more out of sympathy for the soon-to-be-departed Unsworth Government than out of sympathy for the home seeker. However, that back flip was offset by the knee jerk reaction to foreign investment in real estate. What a macabre and contorted dance that was. Nevertheless, what is more important than anything else is the prospect for interest rates. If the Government is not prepared to quicken the pace of adjustment, a move that will allow a sustainable easing of monetary policy, as opposed to the premature easing that we have been seeing, inflation and interest rates will remain high. That is bad for housing; that is bad for investment; and it leaves little prospect of significantly reducing the $83 billion foreign debt, that is, Labor's debt. The quadrupling of that debt has occurred during the period of this Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the criticisms that have been put-and they are significant and substantial-as I have said, the Bills basically put into effect decisions made at the May 1987 Premiers Conference and the Loan Council meeting and the Opposition will not be opposing them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the commitment of the Opposition, as evinced by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), to the general principle underlying the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill and the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill. It is certainly past time that the Commonwealth Government required greater accountability from the States in channelling taxpayers' money to the States. The honourable member for Kooyong spoke against the tendency of the Commonwealth thrusting into realms which he stated were traditionally the responsibility of the States. He does not suggest the wholesale removal of Commonwealth funding for the States but believes in block grants without Commonwealth meddling. I do not think this is reasonable. What is the logic in giving taxpayers' money to State governments for the provision of facilities and/or training without ensuring that the money is spent for the purposes for which it was intended? Certainly experiences with the misspending of Commonwealth funding in Queensland demonstrate the urgent need for the Commonwealth Government to plan ahead and to introduce accountability provisions. This is done in the Bills to hand.

SPEECH.PARA: I comment firstly on the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill 1987. Since the Hawke Government came to office in 1983, Australia has benefited from sustained and intelligent management. This has been achieved despite the fact that the economy we inherited from our predecessors was in a state of recession far worse than expected. This Government has now produced a virtually balanced Budget for the first time in 17 years. The Bills now before the House reflect this responsible economic management as well as the traditional Labor commitment to the welfare needs of this country, particularly long term assistance for low and middle income earners.

In the interests of continuing national economic recovery, one of the purposes of this Bill is to continue the payment of interest free capital grants to the States as part of the State governments' Loan Council programs. In the 10 year prior to 1985-86 the Federal Government's contribution amounted to one-third of the State governments' Loan Council program but was increased during the difficult times of 1985-86 and 1986-87 to approximately 35.7 per cent.

State economies have been assisted greatly since 1970-71 when interest free grants were first introduced. The States are free to administer the grants as they see fit. This Bill provides for $176,104,000 in capital grants in 1987-88 and $357,208,000 makes up the loan portion of the State governments Loan Council programs. In the past five years the States and the Northern Territory have been able to nominate part of the borrowing component of their Loan Council programs for public housing. As a result of a decision made at the Loan Council meeting on 25 May 1987, this Bill seeks to allow the States and the Northern Territory to nominate the whole of the borrowing component of their programs for public housing in 1987-88. Up to $414m will be provided to the States and the Northern Territory as loans on concessional terms for the purposes of public housing.

What distinguishes this Government even more than its economic performance is its ability to reconcile sound fiscal management with a long-standing commitment to social welfare policy, something which Opposition members were unable to do when in government. Nothing more ably demonstrates this dual commitment than public housing. It is important that spending in this area is not ad hoc, as it was in past years, but is planned to meet the needs of Australian electorates. This plan must incorporate the accountability provisions to ensure greater accountability from the States. In past years the Queensland Government has reneged on its responsibilities to Queenslanders by grossly underspending in the area of public housing and missing out on the Federal dollar that it could have had to relieve that situation. I have those figures on file. In the past the Queensland Government has had the freedom to spend, or misspend, Federal Government moneys as it wished. This Bill formalises the requirement that the States and the Northern Territory must supply the Commonwealth with certified financial statements which clearly show the way in which they distributed loan funds nominated for public housing-a most important provison, given the situation in Queensland where that State Government exists without a public accounts committee.

Before the Hawke Government moved to require accountability for too long the Queensland Government had been accountable to no one but itself regarding expenditure in the area of public housing-as well as in most areas of expenditure in Queensland. The requirement for the States and the Northern Territory formally to report on their expenditure to the Commonwealth was long overdue. Queensland has done very well on Federal funding. In 1987-88 the Federal Government has increased public housing funding to the States and the Northern Territory to $700m. At least $700m a year will also be provided to the States as grants under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement in 1988-89 and in 1989-90. Queensland's allocation is as follows: untied grants, $77,545,000; rental assistance for pensioners, $7,396,000; rental assistance for Aborigines, $15,186,000; crisis accommodation program, $2,553,000; mortgage and rent relief scheme-a most important Federal Government initiative for which the Queensland Government has consistently claimed credit-$4,132,000; local government and community housing program, $1,969,000. This makes a total of $108,781,000 of Federal funding for Queensland alone. An additional $414m has also been made available in 1987-88 for public housing under Loan Council nominating arrangements at the highly concessional interest rate of 4.5 per cent repayable over 53 years. This amount includes $24.966m for Queensland.

As a result of the first triennial evaluation of the 1984 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, changes are currently being made to assistance arrangements which will tighten provisions for accountability and use of Loan Council funds to ensure that all revolving funds arising from these loans remain in public housing. The changes will also ensure that States adhere to the non-discrimination principles of the agreement by adding a specific requirement that young, single people be admitted to waiting lists-a most desirable change to these provisions. It will ensure that State governments come to the party in meeting this requirement. We will do this by the provision to allow Federal reallocation of funds if this requirement is not met. Regrettably, this is important, given the past record of the Queensland Government again in not allocating Federal funds for the purposes for which they were intended. Other changes are to revise consultative arrangements for the Aboriginal rental program to ensure greater Aboriginal involvement and a more effective Federal role in overseeing priority setting for Aboriginal housing and to require States to allocate not less than 50 per cent of total funds for public rental housing from 1987-88. Again, these are most important provisions. They are particularly important, given the fact that Queensland currently allocates a higher proportion of its funds to home purchase rather than rental than other States. Public rental housing is desperately needed by those who have not the capital to buy nor the income to pay inflated rental.

Funding granted to States for public rental housing is not, of course, the be-all and end-all of the Hawke Government's demonstrated commitment to housing. The first home owners scheme was introduced in October 1983 to assist first home buyers from the low to middle income range to purchase their homes. The scheme has already provided significant subsidies to 255,000 Australian households and is expected to assist a further 52,000 families in this financial year. Nationally the figures show that 292,494 applications have been received for the first home owners scheme grant. Of these 256,473 were approved amounting to $1,140,476,000. To date, $924,869,000 of that has been paid out. In Queensland alone 54,103 applications were received of which 47,659 have been approved. The amount of money approved totalled $217,594,000 of which $176,184,000 has been paid out. In the electorate of Lilley, which I represent, 1,877 applications were received, of which 1,653 were approved. The amount approved totalled $7,549,000, of which $6,112,000 has been paid out already.

I now wish to refer to the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill 1987. In May 1987, the Premiers Conference reached several agreements regarding the level of financial assistance grants and identified health grants. The purpose of this Bill is to fix the actual amount of financial assistance grants and identified health grants to the States in 1987-88 at certain levels which will be estimated to maintain their value in real terms. The 1985 Premiers Conference had decided to distribute these grants among the States according to the actual increases in the all groups consumer price index in the year ending in the March quarter of each year. The level of financial assistance grants and identified health grants was to be maintained in real terms in 1985-86 and increased by 2 per cent in real terms in the remainder of the triennium. This Bill will change this decision by fixing the grant amounts whilst retaining their value in real terms. The 1987 Premiers Conference decided to fix the total pool of financial assistance and identified health grants to be paid to States at $13.539m. This figure was calculated on an estimated 8 per cent increase on the 1986-87 grants level. This represents the forecast rise in the consumer price index in the year to March 1988.

The Bill currently before the House also seeks to enact decisions announced in the 1987-88 Budget that, commencing on 1 January 1988, the Commonwealth will limit its contributions to State higher education superannuation schemes operating on an `emerging cost' basis. Before detailing some of the provisions of this sector, I would like to comment that the area of State funding on health programs is another area which has been extensively abused, again by the Queensland Government. The state of health programs, particularly women's health centres in Queensland, is an absolute disgrace. Comparatively there is such a gap between the number of women's health centres in Queensland and the number in other States, notably South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria, that the nil situation which has existed in this respect for many years in Queensland is a glaring indictment of the Queensland Government and is indicative of the priority which that Government extends to women and to their health problems.

Regarding the Commonwealth limitation of contributions to State higher education superannuation schemes, I wish to comment that the burden shouldered by higher education institutions striving to finance the accrued liability of emerging cost superannuation schemes has been heavy. Given the projected rise in cost of these schemes in future years reaching into the next century, this load can be expected only to increase. An added and increasing burden was put on some institutions as a result of the 14 per cent limit set by the former Government on the Commonwealth contribution to emerging superannuation costs. We in the Government ranks are aware of this burden. As the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has already indicated in this place, the Government is prepared to play its part in the restructuring of higher education by contributing in a tangible way to the process of growth and improvement that is needed. But all interested sectors in higher education, including State governments, must play a part. The Commonwealth is therefore willing to share superannuation costs with the States.

In the coming months, the Federal Government will address a number of aspects of the operation of our higher education system, including Commonwealth-State relationships in higher education and the problems created for institutions by divided responsibilities and accountability arrangements. Indeed, the Minister has already presented to this House a statement outlining these factors and a Green Paper will be presented by the Government before the end of 1987 setting out the many areas of administration and other matters of concern in higher education which the Government wishes members of the community, both the education community and the outside community, to address. This will be a wide-ranging review, relying heavily on input from the education sector, from business and unions and from the community at large. Meanwhile the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill 1987 requires States to contribute to the costs of higher education superannuation schemes by sharing costs in a way which reflects the respective responsibilities of State and Commonwealth governments which prevailed when the liability was incurred.

The basis of the sharing arrangements, as outlined by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, will be that the States and the Commonwealth will share the cost of accrued liability relevant to the period prior to 1974 on the same basis as the Commonwealth matched State funds for higher education at that time. The Commonwealth will bear the full cost of accrued liability between 1974 and 1981, and the States and the Commonwealth will share the cost of accrued liability post-1981 on the basis of the Commonwealth meeting all costs up to a limit of 14 per cent of salaries of staff in superannuation schemes. The Commonwealth will provide full funding for superannuation costs in its grants to institutions and will recover the State shares. Overall, the changes introduced by way of the States grants amendment Bills before this House reflect a sustained and effective commitment to the dual objective of responsible economic management and real and continuing assistance to low and middle income earners, such as those wishing to take advantage of public rental housing. State accountability in spending Commonwealth funding is an integral part of meeting this commitment.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Victorian Cement Industry-Wayne Gardner-Australian Constitution-Sri Lanka-Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome: Social Attitudes-Pennyroyal Herb Farm-Merino Ram Exports-Mount Druitt Community Youth Support Scheme-St Saviours Cathedral: Goulburn-Eighteenth Wanden Silvan Field Day

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the House a very difficult problem for the cement industry in Victoria. I refer specifically to the cement plant at Traralgon. The problem that is looming is simple and calls for immediate government action. At present there is an importer operating out of Western Australia called Independent Cement and Lime Pty Ltd which has been importing raw cement in the form of clinker cement from South East Asia-specifically from Indonesia, I believe. The cement is being imported at a dump price level. This is an emerging problem and I understand that Cockburn Cement Ltd in Western Australia will be filing an official complaint so as to trigger the anti-dumping laws. I stress that this clinker cement is about three-quarters of the way through the process to get to cement for retailing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Gippsland cement industry is concerned because it is understood that there is an importer in Victoria who will shortly be importing cement in its finished form, which makes this an even greater problem. I understand that cement of this type can be imported at $A63.50 per tonne, and with delivery and handling costs it rises to about $91. That figure of $91 compares with the Australian price of $123. One can see immediately that the imported cement being dumped in Australia at a dump price level will seriously jeopardise the cement market in Victoria. That Victorian market is about 1.4 million tonnes a year split, 86,000 tonnes for Gippsland and the rest among all the other companies. There are about 770 employees in the industry in Victoria, but that does not include contract drivers. For Gippsland itself there are 102 employees, but one must add to that about 20 contractors. One compares that large employment opportunity with the position of the importers, who have only a handful of employees, mostly shuffling paper, although no doubt some of them will be contractors.

Revenue to the State Government in the form of tax from all the companies in the Victorian cement industry is a massive $38m. Of that figure Gippsland provides $2.7m to the State. The Federal take from Gippsland is $810,000 a year and the total amount of money poured into the local community is $4.4m. It is most important that the Victorian importer does not obtain a foothold, as apparently occurred in Western Australia. I am led to understand that a site very close to the unloading port has been purchased in Port Melbourne. It is a $2.4m site and the building of silos is shortly to be undertaken, if that has not already happened. SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a few words tonight about the Constitution. Our Constitution is a fundamentally important document in the sort of society we have in Australia. One of the favourite techniques of the Labor Party to undermine our Constitution is to say that the Constitution was formulated at the turn of the century, is now out of date and, as a result, ought to be criticised and changed. I see a member of the Labor Party on the back benches nodding his head in agreement. I would say that he will stay there. Obviously, things have changed since 1901. Any- body knows that. It is a clear fact. The real issue is whether our Constitution is still relevant in the 1980s. The answer is a resounding yes. We need first to understand what our Constitution is about. The Constitution establishes the divisions of power within our society and the manner in which we organise the judiciary, the legislature and the Executive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lord Reith of Flinders.

—Lord Reith founded the British Broadcasting Corporation and ought to be beyond criticism by the likes of the honourable member. Leaving aside Lord Reith, let me say that one of the great things about our Constitution is that it provides a system of checks and balances by the doctrine of the separation of powers among the three arms of government, as well as by introducing checks and balances within them. In Australia we have a bicameral system comprising the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Constitutional Commission recently brought down some proposals which it described as `a new scheme for the Parliament'. To describe its proposals as new is really stretching the definition of the word `new'. Let me take honourable members back to the joint report of this Parliament in 1959 where many of the proposals now described as new by the Constitutional Commission were put forward. Dealing with the issue of the importance of bicameral parliaments as a means of providing a mechanism against the excesses of the Executive, the dissenting report of Senator Reg Wright, as he was then, is well worth reading.
—What about the ID card?
—The honourable member for Hotham, who was prepared to stand up on the ID card and oppose excesses of government, ought to be interested in this. Senator Wright quoted John Stuart Mill, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: A majority in a single assembly, when it has assumed a permanent character-when composed of the same persons habitually acting together, and always assured of victory in their own House-easily becomes despotic and overweaning, if released from the necessity of considering whether its acts will be concurred in by another constituent authority. The same reason which induced the Romans to have two Consuls makes it desirable there should be two Chambers: that neither of them may be exposed to the corrupting influence of undivided power, even for the space of a single year.
Thirty years on, those words are still true and that provision of our Constitution is still worthwhile.

It concludes: `The relationship between what adolescents know and how they behave is perhaps the most salient issue'.

The gap between what young people, indeed citizens of all ages, know and the way they behave and the judgments they make is not perhaps the most salient issue; it is the most salient issue. What the AIDS epidemic has revealed above all else is what has been called AIDS in the moral and spiritual realm. In reflecting on the strategy we should adopt to address the spread of AIDS, we should focus on the success of an intellectual virus which has first invaded the various areas of this society's intellectual and moral defence system, and then rendered that system incapable of discerning those ideas and that behaviour which produce fundamental social degeneration.

One of the main contributing factors in this gradual loss of the capacity to identify what is right and wrong has been the paralysis of this Parliament and of governments of all political persuasion. We see evidence of the now familiar pattern in liberal democracies of powerful minority interest groups vetoing or intimidating policy makers. In this case the political power of homosexual groups and progressive opinion makers in our community has prevented parliaments and governments from even speaking the truth about the centrality of promiscuity and homosexuality in spreading death. I say `even' speaking the truth. I should say that that has been the most successful and crucial area of political neutralisation. Because, as our knowledge of God informs us, it is the speaking of the Word which brings forth life. The greatest success of those who have controlled policy discussions thus far has been their ability to compromise the truth, to ensure that the moral interpretation of our predicament is blurred. It has been that blurring of the truth, the watering down of what we say to our young people and ourselves about sexuality, about human relations, about love, about self-control, about human nature, about God, that has produced the obviously weak and self-deluding AIDS policies and laws we have put in place. When we take a lead in speaking the truth about promiscuity, drug self-abuse and sodomy, and when we place ourselves under the authority of what is right, then we will be able to equip our children and young people to move from technical knowledge of their bodies to the wisdom and prudence which enables judgment. Then we will truly be fulfilling the high duty to the public good which so often goes unfulfilled.
