TALK.START.PARA: —Last year Australia exported nearly 70,000 live merino rams to the Middle East out of a total of 7.7 million sheep that we sent to that part of the world. As government policy states that only a few hundred intact merino rams can be sent out of our country each year, the present quota being 500, and as these rams have to be sold through certain designated auctions in Australia, all of these 70,000 rams to the Middle East had to be sterilised. The rationale behind the quota system, as everyone will know, is to prevent overseas countries having unlimited access to our merino genetic material. Whether one agrees with that policy or not-I am one who opposes the restrictions-I believe there is an overwhelming case for having the merino rams sent to the Middle East exempted from the sterilisation process.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of these merino rams that go to the Middle East for slaughter come from breeding studs that cull a number of their rams out as unsuitable to sell to their clients for breeding purposes. A percentage of rams also comes from those left over after the Australian buyers have picked through the rams that are offered for sale. A few old rams may also come from those at the end of their working life. Clearly, these rams are not wanted by Australian breeders. They are culls because of such factors as low yield, genetic defects, unsuitable wool type, poor fertility or whatever. If sold in the domestic sale yards they would make about $10 a head. However, if shipped to the Middle East, with its culinary preference for live male animals, they can be sold here for about $25 a head.

To comply with the quota regulations to render them infertile all these rams once had to be vasectomised. This was a costly exercise-about $2.50 a head-and the rams had to be done several days prior to loading to allow them to recover at least partially from the vasectomy. This operation involved cutting into the scrotal sac and removing a piece of the vas deferens to block sperm transport from the testicles. However, as the rams had to be held in large, dusty yards, bacterial infection was common causing swelling at the site of the operation and sometimes a febrile reaction and death in a small percentage.

Vasectomy was eventually replaced by an injection of a formaldehyde solution into the epididymis at the base of the testicles. The extensive tissue reaction and scarring that results blocks sperm transport. While this procedure avoided exposing an open wound for infection the cost was still high and the irritant effect the formalin had on live tissue often led to large swellings. It placed an added stress on the animal at a time when the body had to combat other stresses such as anthrax vaccination. The odd death would still occur. Of course, neither of the procedures guaranteed 100 per cent infertile rams as neither is 100 per cent foolproof. As well, it often takes many months for all reserve semen supplies to be flushed out of the reproductive system. An argument exists that if the job had to be done, it should have been done properly or not at all. To ensure total freedom of semen each ram would have to be electroejaculated at a later date-an exercise that would be totally impractical and uneconomic. So, we can see that whatever operation is used, it is both stressful and costly, and sterility cannot be guaranteed.

However, I also believe that the whole procedure is totally unnecessary. This is because no country that is in the serious wool producing business would want to import these rams from the Middle East. Firstly, the rams are mainly culls, and interested countries would have better stock on hand anyway. There would be no way they would buy a cull ram of dubious fertility when they could buy a better one by less devious means on the open market. Secondly, and of paramount importance, is the point that it would be insanity for another country to jeopardise its health record by importing rams from the Middle East. One has only to look at the extensive lists of health tests that have to be done on rams going from Australia to countries like China to realise how careful they are on this matter.

Once sheep arrive in the Middle East they can be exposed to a whole host of serious diseases from which the import breeding countries are free-scrapie, bluetongue, screw worm fly, sheep pox and so on. To think that these countries would put at risk the enormous capital investment they have in their flocks simply to get their hands on a few nondescript culls of unknown fertility and performance is laughable. The sterilisation requirement of live merino rams to the Middle East is ridiculous and should be scrapped. Fortunately, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has now recognised this and recommended such action to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). I am delighted to hear that the Minister has accepted this advice which has now been operational since 1 October. I appreciate that the export of any live merino sheep is an emotional decision for some people. However, I urge all in the merino breeding industry in Australia to recognise the necessity of this decision and to give it their full support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to draw the attention of the Parliament, and in particular the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to a very important project that is currently under way in my electorate of Gilmore in the city of Goulburn, in the heart of Gilmore. It is the completion of the construction of St Saviours Cathedral belltower and spire. The first Bishop of Goulburn, Bishop Thomas, commissioned the well-known colonial architect, Edmund Blacket, to design a cathedral for the city of Goulburn. Construction of this magnificent cathedral began in 1874 and was completed to its present stage in 1884. St Saviours Cathedral serves as a cathedral church for Canberra and the Australian Capital Territory and for about one-seventh of the total area of New South Wales. Therefore, it is a very important part of the religious life of the people in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: The cathedral is a magnificent construction. It is regarded as one of the greatest examples of gothic architecture throughout the world. It took 10 years to build and one of the reasons it took so long was the very intricate and detailed stone carving which took place at the time of its construction. It has been described by many people as probably Australia's richest church interior. Since the completion in 1884 of the first stage there have been a number of attempts to finalise the tower, to build a spire and to install bells. The latest round of that began in 1975 when a committee was formed in Goulburn to complete the final stage of the tower and spire. In 1976 the committee was very lucky to be able to acquire stone from the demolished Fitzroy Bridge which was stockpiled in the hope that there would be money in the years ahead to utilise it for the completion of the tower.

In 1983 the committee made an application to the Australian Bicentennial Authority for funding for the completion of the tower, spire and bells as a bicentennial project. It was fortunate enough to get funding for this project and this is what has financed to date the works for the completion of this tower. At the moment there is a need for more money. The bells for the tower were not included in the grant, however, the Goulburn City Council has, through its bicentennial committee, purchased eight bells from St Marks Church in Leicester, England. Specialist architects and a team of selected stone masons have been engaged on the project since July 1986. I am proud to say that construction work is well ahead of schedule and is very much up to a standard that any artisan would like to apply. Funds in hand are insufficient to enable the completion of this unique architectural treasure. At present there is a need for approximately $1.25m to finalise this very ambitious project. The matter is becoming urgent. The reason it is becoming urgent is that very shortly funds will run out. At present all the scaffolding is in place. The craftsmen are there on the job. It is a rare commodity to have craftsmen with these skills. If the project is stopped and money is raised later, it is unlikely that these artisans will be able to be called upon readily. I am afraid that we may lose the opportunity we now have of completing this ambitious project.

What I am asking from the Parliament and from the Treasurer is that donations made to St Saviours tower and spire be made tax deductible. It seems ironic that donations made to St Saviours Cathedral restoration fund are tax deductible, but through some quirk of nature it is not deemed by the Commissioner of Taxation that donations to the tower and spire appeal are eligible as tax deductible items. I know that there are a number of people who would be happy to give generously to this very worthwhile project if the Government were able to declare these donations tax deductible. This is a very ambitious program and one of which every Australian can be proud. It is the only construction of its type in the world today. Some of the skills that have applied at present have not been applied for more than 100 years. It is a useful employer and it is something of which every Australian will be proud if we can acquire the funds to complete it.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 October the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) (Hansard, p. 752-3) asked me a question without notice concerning actions taken by the Government to put pressure on the Government of Ethiopia to allow the balance of black Jews in Ethiopia to join their families in Israel. I undertook to obtain the relevant information and can now provide the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government shares the concern expressed about the situation of the Jewish community in Ethiopia.
The plight of those individuals who are separated from their immediate families is obviously particularly distressing there, as it is elsewhere in the world.
The Government has received representations on behalf of these people from members of the Australian Jewish community and other sources, such as Amnesty International.

Regarding the specific situation of those Ethiopian Jews who wish to join their families in Israel, the power and standing of the Australian Government to intervene are obviously limited, as the matter is primarily one between the Governments of Ethiopia and Israel.

Nevertheless the Government has done what it can to help. As recently as 31 August this year the general situation of the Ethiopian Jews, especially the restriction being placed on their emigration, and alleged Ethiopian policies of dispersal, was raised with the Ethiopian authorities in a note verbale from our Ambassador in Addis Ababa.
The Government will pursue a formal reply from the Ethiopian authorities and we will keep the matter under review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the British Government freezes the pensions of its citizens living abroad at the rate payable when first drawn.
(2) What is the shortfall of income from the UK to Australia for UK pensioners living in Australia as a result of the pension freeze in (a) 1985-86 and (b) 1986-87.
(3) What would be the cost to the taxpayer of supplementing UK pensions as a result of the freeze in (a) 1985-86 and (b) 1986-87.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) UK pensions payable in a number of countries overseas are paid at the rate in force when the pensioner leaves the UK or when he or she first qualifies for a UK pension if abroad at that time. The bulk of the UK pensioners paid at frozen rates are in Australia (over 99,000), Canada (over 56,000) and New Zealand (more than 23,000).
A further 140,000 former residents of the UK receive payment of indexed pensions while abroad.

(2) Precise figures are not available. As at October 1986, however, the UK Government estimated that the extra cost of uprating pensions paid at that time into Australia was at least 73 million Pounds Sterling per year.
(3) Based on 1986 figures, the estimated annual savings to Australia which could result from full indexation of British pensions are in the order of $A75 million.

The honourable member would be aware that non-indexation of UK pensions has been an issue facing this and previous Governments for over 15 years. In February 1986, I announced our intention to seek a renegotiation of the current reciprocal social security agreement with the UK to provide for indexation of UK pensions.

Since then moves have been made to pressure the UK Government. As part of these measures, the Prime Minister has written to the UK Prime Minister and I have made a joint approach with the Canadian Minister for Health and Welfare to our UK counterpart.
None of these measures has been successful to date. The UK Government contends that it cannot afford to index its pensions paid into Australia at the present time.
However the Government will consider further steps which could be taken to press the UK on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 24 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are letters from the Minister's Department forwarded to individuals and corporations marked ``Postage Paid'', without date stamping. If so, are there significant revenue savings from these measures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Approximately 30% of Departmental letters posted within Australia are marked ``Postage Paid'' without being date stamped. This bulk postage process is generally used for the distribution of pro forma correspondence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: What steps will his Department take to ensure that the 200,000 eligible low income families who are not Social Security recipients are aware of their entitlement to the Family Allowance Supplement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government recognises how important it is to ensure that all potential eligible families are aware of their entitlement to the Family Allowance Supplement.
A national project manager has been appointed with specific responsibility for developing an extensive information and publicity campaign.

The overall strategy will involve targeting organisations likely to have direct contact with low income families. These will include community organisations, schools, child and community care centres as well as employers and trade unions with lower pay structures or a predominantly female labour force.
In addition, a co-ordinated community outreach program is planned and this will involve departmental staff at the local regional office level.
These activities will be supplemented by an innovative campaign of media advertising.

The Department will automatically transfer those who are receiving Family Income Supplement (FIS) to the new payment. In the course of requesting recipients of Family Allowance to declare their income so that the new Family Allowance income test could be applied, the Department notified each allowee of the FIS income limit applicable in their case and has been granting FIS to eligible respondents.
